Coming in midday Saturday, we didn't have as many choices as we would have expected - there were six different kinds. I chose to try the salted caramel, almond and vanilla. ALL WERE AMAZING! I was already full from lunch, so pleasing my taste buds on a full stomach means it's good.

The macaroon itself had a large shell with just the right texture - crunchy on the outside but soft and chewy on the inside. The filling for the salted caramel was amazing, swirls of carmel and whatever else they put in there...I highly recommend this flavor!

I've read great reviews about the green tea, but those were coming out of the oven when we were there. I'll definitely be back to try all the different flavors they offer and probably won't eating any other types of macaroons besides the Fillmore Bakeshop ones. NOM NOM
author: Mimi V.

description:
I frequent here about 2-3 times per month.  Just love it.
Usually it is mid-morning, so coffee and a Danish is the order of the day.
They even heat them up for you.

Definetly a good place.
author: Joe S.

description: I went in to ask if they ship their cakes.  Long story short they weren't very nice and just told me they couldn't help me.  I was trying to understand their cake and the more questions I asked the more irrate and snooty they got.  I asked under my breath why the lady was being so mean.   Then the woman helping me started being curt.  I may not look like the Pavific Hgts Today, big no reason for being mean to anyone that walks into your store.   You just never know who will walk in! They just couldn't get that my fault was being enthusiastic about their cake!!  And!  We were going to order maccaroons but the woman no longer wanted to help us!?!
author: Celeste F.

description:
Finally got to try a cronut!! Or what Fillmore Bakeshop calls D's Nutz. Lol.  I read on yelp that they sell cronuts on Saturdays from 9-10 am so I made sure to arrive accordingly.  Sadly, I didn't make it there until closer to 10 am.  I thought they would all be gone but luckily, after an hourish wait, I got my hands on a box of cinnamon sugar cronuts and their special of day, maple bacon.  

I scurried off to the car to take a bite of them while they were still hot (since there were not seats inside; only two tables).  OMG, so amazing.  I'm not sure what legit cronuts are supposed to taste like but these were delicious.  Fluffy, light, crispy, not too oily.  Yum!  

I say brave the line, maybe not around 9 am since you don't really need to, because these cronuts are worth it.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Accidentally found this place but I'm glad I did.  I needed to get a dessert for a family dinner so I decided to get a pumpkin cheesecake.  It looked so pretty with the chocolate curls with fall-colored leaves ontop of the cheesecake.  The cheesecake was a tad pricey but it was delicious and creamy.

I also had to get a piece of the chocolate banana bread pudding (for myself at a later time).  Another good decision.  I took the lady recommendation and warmed it up a bit.  Yum!
author: Rose A.

description:
Hate to jump on the fauxnuts bandwagon. But they are pretty good. I hate that its becoming a weekly event to check their Facebook early on Saturday mornings for the new flavor and then journeying over to Fillmore to wait in line with my fellow suckers. But such is life. Best fake-cronuts in the city so far, and NO I HAVEN'T tried them all yet. Ok maybe.

Having tried the original one in nyc I must say I think Fillmore does a really good job. One thing it has over Dominique Ansel is that they serve them warm if you go early in the morning. 9ish. Warm cronuts are like warm Krispy Kreme on crack x100. I was disappointed with the new york version because I was used to Fillmore's warm and fresh version. Both have their pros. But it's def a great substitute until you make it to nyc. And less hassle. 

I will also mention their rotating bread puddings. Love it. Once I found a pecan in it though. They told me they use day-old pastries for it, so they may or may not contain nuts depending on what leftover pastries they have left. FYI just in case you are allergic. My favorite so far is the blueberry.
author: Augusto M.

description: The two danishes I bought here were delicious. The latte was the perfect compliment to the crispy raisin nut sweetness of the pastries. The diversity of the food in the shop was impressive highlighted by some creative meringue treats and hazelnut additions to breads . All of it was being made in house and they were super helpful. Additionally, the serving dishes were unique, functional, and modern in design. I definitely want to come back and sample more of their food.
author: Dominique S.

description:
Oh, you, cronut!  How I do love thee!  The cronut is now my new guilty pleasure after trying for the very first time today.  Now, I get what all the fuss is about.  The texture is really like the marriage between a flaky croissant and a soft doughy donut.  It's on the sweet side when it's encrusted with sugar, but it's so easy to just brush that off and make this diabetic's nightmare pastry a little more "healthy."  ;)

Service is good...greeted with a fappy face behind the counter.

$9 for two cronuts and one order of bread pudding (a fave of my mom's, not mine).

I'll be back for a cronut, and maybe try the lavendar short bread cookie and the lavender sea salt macaroon.
author: Michelle N.

description: I was visiting SF for 3 days and stopped by Filmore Bakeshop each morning...fresh, delicious pastries and finally someone who knows how to make Dry Machiatto!!!!! I cant wait to go back. Im now in search of a similar place in LA
author: Irene G.

description:
A year later, and I still go to Fillmore Bakeshop at least once a week. I've explored lots of their menu and can still say almost everything is outstanding. 

They just got a new espresso machine and can now do more drinks faster, so order away!

The pretzel croissant is the unsung hero of that bakery; it's more like an everything-bagel croissant and it's savory and nutty and flaky and amazing. I get one almost every time, and they're almost never sold out. 

Cronuts are always good, they just started offering meringue cookies (!!), and on Saturday mornings the foccicias are still awesome (almost always have pesto-bacon, jalepeno, or artichoke). They've opened up their repertoire to a larger selection of cookies, candies, bites, and bars. The quiche lorraine has a beautiful texture and strong, real, swiss cheese and whole slices of bacon laced through it; rich and savory crust that doesn't fall apart when you bite into it. Morning buns and cinnamon-raisin snails are also lovely and never too sweet. 

Not everyone will love the style of macaron they do, but I still think they're good. Same goes for the danishes, which can be a little soggy later in the day (but that's any danish). And I feel like this is the only possible negative, and seems to be what most people try. As a regular, I'd say to taste more of the menu than just macarons and danishes -- ask the ladies at the register what's good right now and they'll always give you great recs.

Service is great, products are homemade and lovely, and I've only had stellar experiences with the staff. I'll be SO sad when I move away from Lower Pacific Heights, and won't be able to walk over to Fillmore Bakeshop everyday; they've truly defined so much of my life and this neighborhood for me. Thank you!
author: Laura J.

description: We stopped by Fillmore for something sweet to eat after lunch. I tried their salted caramel and hazelnut macaroons. The caramel was my favorite.
author: My P.

description: Sweets and cakes look amazing and are pretty good. Really friendly and patient staff!
author: Elena P.

description:
yum yum yum.. 
nom nom nom..

One word! Macarons!

As I say in most of my Macaron reviews, I do not like authentic French Macarons (they are too sweet for me). Yes I have had macarons from Chantal Guillon , La boulange, Laduree (NY) and numerous other local bakeries.. but Filmore has the #1 best macarons!

These macarons have a crispy outer shell, and once you get past the crunchy-ness, your teeth sink into this soft but chewyy area right before you reach the delicious filling. I love love love the chewyness It makes me feel like I am eating something a little more hearty than a dinky little macaroon.

There are a variety of flavors, Pistachio was my favorite.

These come at $1.95 a pop. Well worth the drive.
author: Sharon N.

description:
After a stressful day, I sought out a shop that would sell me yummy treats and this place seemed promising.

The place itself is cute. HUGE display cases with TONS of sweets of various kinds. What caught my attention first were the French macarons so of course I bought three for myself: green tea, coconut, and strawberry. The guy helping me at the time was really nice and helped me choose flavors. 

They seemed hugely portioned and I was wary of them, but I bought 'em anyway. $1.85 each, the prices seemed standard. After leaving with them, I realized that the quality of these macarons don't match up with the price.

The macaron part caved in on all of them so I had a smashed up mess. I guess it doesn't matter because I'd be eating them either way, but my impression is that these macarons were not made right. Macarons shouldn't cave in like that! The only plus side to these macarons is that they have great flavor. This much I cannot deny.

Overall, cute bakery but I expected more from the macarons.
author: Sofia R.

description: Was disappointed upon arrival to find out  they only have cronuts available Wednesdays through Saturdays from 9am to noon. I came for a cronut but alas, I left with a lackluster morning bun and yummy but short-falling almond croissant.
author: Lucy D.

description: OMG! Delicious. Yesterday was my aunty birthday. I want special cake, so I didn't want to go to costco or Safeway to buy it. I asked my boss, and he recommended this place. With storm and rain and parking issue finally I made it 15 min to close! Even though I was last minute costumer, they were welcoming and great. I got chocolate hazelnut cake, and she made a beautiful happy birthday sign for it.  The best part was when we had the first bite. OMG it was heaven. I didn't eat such a delicious cake for long. Now I know where to get my cakes. I can't wait till try all their selections.
author: Baharak A.

description: So sad they no longer serve cronuts. I literally drive halfway across the City to go here for cronuts. Yes, they have other yummy treats on offer, but it is the cronuts that makes my trip worth it. I sincerely hope they fix their fryer and offer cronuts once again. I would love to continue to be their customer.
author: Funk G.

description:
They sell Swedish Princess Cakes by the slice. I might come back to edit this after I try Schubert's but it was very good, definitely worth the hype.

The cronut was great, come early to grab one because they do run out!
author: Clare Y.

description:
A must for me...Macaroons.

The massively flavored macaroons are the things that constantly keep me making a detour here to Fillmore Bakeshop. These round two-inched delights are extremely worth the $1.95 price tag for each piece.  Why?  There's no guessing what flavor is what.  Each macaroon flavor has a very distinct flavoring. It's like biting in to a raspberry, an orange or eating a handful of pistachios. Pistachio along with Blackberry, are the two that are my absolute favorite flavor of choice during the past few visits I've made here.  

On today's particular visit, I feasted on just the Mango which was deliciously sweet and tangy.  I bought a dozen macaroons, which gives you the 13th Free, for a gathering of friends this evening.  I figured a variety would be best. So I chose Honey Lavender, Blood Orange, Mango, Pistachio, Salted Caramel, and Blackberry. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/9OKUEFQiWLntDYhpwCaJcg?select=Pz4OvNcHjpgRiLr1sd_qMQ#tu-uRhrDMFHIu5oi8g9-9w

The have a variety of other baked goods and sweets. I've tried their Almond Croissant and it is also delicious, from the light and fluffy insides, to the perfectly baked crisp outside and sprinkled with just the right amount of powdered sugar.  Perfect morning treat. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/9OKUEFQiWLntDYhpwCaJcg?select=Pz4OvNcHjpgRiLr1sd_qMQ#JFFo_-HQEbSlcgoG9pi6wA

A new favorite of mine!
author: Cass J.

description:
"We're just two sweet ladies with a blowtorch."
Pastry chef to fellow pastry chef (and customers), overheard at Fillmore Bakeshop by Adda Dada

Public Eavesdropping in the San Francisco Chronicle's LEAH GARCHIK column 12/6/2012 

Read more: http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/Stand-up-you-re-rocking-the-boat-4094690.php#ixzz2EGG0QSNo
author: Addadada A.

description: This was my first visit. The cronuts are good. That was my first cronut so I had no expectation. A little too much sugar but you can always dust it off. It would be nice if they heat up the cronut a bit too. The bread pudding that day was blueberry. I think it's ok. Nothing spectacular. No bathroom so thats minus 1 star :(
author: Inez J.

description:
I am a bit ashamed that I've been here 4 Saturdays within the last 5. Of course I came for the special flavored cronut of the day (read all recent reviews for time and day for special flavors). I've had the cinnamon sugar, smores, coffee crunch, and cookies & cream. The best flavor is by far coffee crunch. Each special flavor is $3 or $3.50. If you haven't had a cronut, you should try at least one in your lifetime and if you're in the Bay Area, Fillmore Bakeshop should really be the place to try it. 

I've also tried the almond croissant, jalapeno focaccia, pumpkin pie, and blood orange macaron.
The almond croissant (3.5 stars) has a special type of almond paste with a slight flavor of orange zest to it. Mine had very little almond paste in it and was all to one side. I'm am almond croissant fanatic and was a little disappointed.
Jalapeno focaccia (4 stars) was cheesy and flavorful and was the perfect amount to hold me up for lunch. It is greasy though. HELLO PIMPLES!
Pumpkin pie (2 stars) was extremely bland and I wanted to shake some pumpkin pie spice over it. Expensive, I think about $4/slice, and not satisfying at all.
Blood orange macaron (3 stars) had a nice texture, but I thought it was overly sweet and tasted like orange soda.

The staff is always friendly and it's entertaining to watch the bakers frosting cakes and making more cronuts (but a little disturbing when you see them dunking their entire hand into frosting-like ingredients and plopping it into the KitchenAid instead of using actual measuring cups). The only complaint I really have is to label all items. On Saturdays, the place is so lined up with cronut fanatics that it's difficult to find out what is what. There were many goodies that were not labeled and that led me to accidentally getting a slice of bland pumpkin pie (the pumpkin pie label was in front of focaccia bread and I thought it was a special ass type of pumpkin pie). 

Because I've had so many cronuts in the past few weeks, it's time to go back to real donuts or croissants, but once Fillmore Bakeshop produces those coffee crunch ones, I'm running back! 

I hope they don't start making crappy cronuts cause this morning, the cookies and cream cronuts we got were undercooked and very doughy and chewy on the inside.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
I love this place so much, I went twice two days in a row to get a baker's dozen of their macarons....

I can't say much for the "authenticity" of their macarons (no idea what it should be like), but compared to a couple other places I've tried (like Miette), I enjoy the macarons from Fillmore Bakeshop much more! They're $1.95 a piece, and if you get a dozen, they throw in the 13th to make a baker's dozen for free.

They're a lot fatter than the ones I've had from other places, and they have some interesting flavors. I tried root beer the other day. Wow. Flavor explosion!
author: Munnie T.

description:
A quiet corner bakeshop tucked away in Pacific Heights that would've gone unnoticed by me if I hadn't wrote down the address and backtracked since I missed it the first time. I swear I am bad at reading store signs if they are on the same side of the street as I am walking, the proximity - it's just too close! There was window art outside of plates of sweets and cakes. They also had of Giants paraphernalia inside in the form of baked goods, reppin' SF hard, I see. 

I got the honey lavender and root beer macarons, love the more unorthodox flavors they offer. However, warning: the macaron shells are super puffy and thick, especially in proportion to the filling. The first time I had these I wasn't as bothered because the macarons were fresher, but this time the thickness and dryness of the macaron was really apparent. It wasn't chewy and cracked as it was bitten, not reminiscent of a macaron at all. 

The slice of princess cake I ordered was light and fresh; I only had a qualm with the marzipan but overall, it was crumbly scrumptious with two layers of not-too-sweet custard.
author: Alice L.

description:
Bring 6 "D's nutz" to work on a friday and you will be loved!

Yes yes, Fillmore bakeshop has an excellent version of a kronut that you need to sit down with extra napkins and a glass of milk to eat- its amazing. But - fusion pastry fads aside... Try the other items! I live a couple blocks away and it takes everything in me to Not walk in there in the morning on the way to the bus. 

Other faves: chocolate croissant, s'mores bar!!, chocolate chip nut cookie, just had A Pretzel there yesterday that was to die for and only 2 dollars! also there was a mousse cake that was soo decadent my husband picked up last week.

Don't want to knock other Local shops but think twice before you stop at sift or la boulange...this is a true pastry and bakeshop!
author: Angelica M.

description: Blondie was good, but no iced drinks in summer, and my friends chocolate croissant was dry and not very chocolatey. Disappointing given the other reviews.
author: Anthony M.

description: I wish I could write more about Fillmore Bakeshop, but honestly, I only had the pistachio macaron, which was okay in my opinion, but a little too sweet and chewy. The employees are very friendly, which was nice and the store seemed very clean! Will be back
author: Joyce E.

description:
I woke up one morning at the Kabuki Hotel and strolled over to get some coffee. 

As I walked turned the corner of the Fillmore Bakeshop, the smells coming from there were just too hard to resist. 

Needless to say, in addition to the coffee, I bought 5 different pastries and breads and shared a delightful morning with friends. 

The bakery has a wonderful selection that reminds me of amazing bakeries in Europe. 

It will be worth it to get there, just try to get there early so that the other items don't sell out!
author: Shawn S.

description: The cronuts were good.  They started doling them out 5 minutes ahead of time before the line began to form so we felt like we were getting away with something.  The cinnamon ones tasted like the best elephant ear you've ever eaten.  Yeah...I'm comparing it to fair food.  Sorry.  The salted caramel was good but I wouldn't have to get it again.  The pain au chocolate...that was sad.  There was the equivalent of 6 chocolate chips inside.  Super disappointing.
author: A. S.

description:
Yes the kronuts were tasty and the quiche Lorraine was divine. The pies were ok, a slice of cherry and apricot. The crust was flaky but flat. Even the unknown flavor of macaron was good.

Why then the two star rating? Customer service, horrible. We're in line forever and you won't take our order for things other than kronuts until we're at the register? Kronut order taker refuses to help with anything else so that she stands idle with nothing to do? One person for fetching kronuts for the cashier exclusively? Cashier doesn't know what kind of macarons he selling? I felt like I was inconveniencing the cashier by ordering more items beyond kronuts. They're a great fad to bring people in, but why wouldn't you promote your other baked goods? It doesn't matter how good your products are if the people serving them to customers are uppity and inefficient.
author: James S.

description: The macaroons were really tasty, although a bit overpriced. The almond stick I had, was slightly harder than I was expecting. Customer service was good and got my baked goods in a reasonable amount of time for it being a Sunday morning.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Recently started working a few blocks away and couldn't wait to stop by for the infamous cronut! Unfortunately, those don't make it out until 9am, which doesn't work with my 8-5 work schedule. Instead of leaving empty handed, the few times I've stopped in I grabbed a box full of goodies to bring home to the fam. 
I definitely suggest the danishs (just got a pear-cranberry, excited to try!), veggie croissant (spinach, mushrooms, & feta, yum!), and the bookies (oatmeal-choc chip w/ cranberries and nuts).

Great little bakery, with an awesome neighborhood feel (and relatively low prices, esp for pac heights)! Definitely prefer it over the more upscale, expensive bakeries in the area!
author: Sofia J.

description:
Why do you need to go to New York and try the special cronut? Fillmore Bakeshop will give you the best cronut you will ever encounter. I have to say, it is so much better than the one I had in New York. 

Cinnamon sugar cronut- This is my favorite. It tastes like a cinnamon sugar donut but has the texture of a croissant. I love both croissants and donuts, and I think this little treat will fulfill both cravings at once. It's just phenomenal. No other comment.

Sea salt cronut with chocolate swirl- I didn't like this one as much. Don't get me wrong. It is still delicious with little pretzel pieces complementing it. However, my dad and my sister liked this one more. I guess I'm just more of the person that likes originals meaning I don't usually add condiments to my food, so maybe this is the reason why.

Try for yourself! It is definitely worth waking up before 10 on a Saturday morning to grab a few of these addicting cronuts. No regrets.
author: Wendy T.

description:
FINALLY! I've found another GOOD bakery in SF!!!

After discovering Thorough Bread on Church some 3 or 4 years ago, I've tried almost every bakery in the city with hopes of finding another consistent, high quality bakery, but none could compare. Skip the overrated-and-always-overcrowded-hipster Tartine Bakery and get your booty to Fillmore Bakeshop.

Their bread pudding was terrifyingly delicious. The day we went they were serving boysenberry bread pudding. I don't really like cooked berry anything in general, but this wasnt too bad. The perfectly sweet, thick, and smooth mouthfeel of the custard innards amazingly complements the crisp chunks of croissant.  The egg flavor really shines through, a delicious flavor you don't really get at bakery chains like La Boulange.

The almond croissant was a little too underbaked and lacking that foodgasmical textured flakiness that defines a croissant (Yes, I have to make up words when I write food reviews because my experiences and feelings cannot be expressed within the constraints of English), but the frangipane, which was oddly brown in color, was bursting with flavor. Ohhhh, so delish! 

The three of us were pretty full after splitting these two pastries and downing a cuppa "cuafee" each, but my father couldn't resist trying another pastry. He tactfully selected an almond peach croissant, whose delicate flakiness and crispy edges made up for the plain almond croissant's breadiness.

In addition to the scrumptious pastries and baked goods, the staff was pleasant and the head baker (haven't formally met him yet) was very charming.  He seems to have a lot of regulars that he personally interacts with. Nothing better than customer loyalty and neighborhood charm.

So happy. So happy to have found another SF bakery worth frequenting.
author: Colleen W.

description:
Cronuts: The croissant-doughnut hybrid craze from NYC that's sweeping the nation. Fillmore Bakeshop makes them locally and they're called D's Nutz. I was prepared to give this place a 5 star rating as I'd had the Cronuts once before, albiet not fresh out of the oven. So you can imagine my excitement when I was awake early enough on a Sunday to get a fresh Cronut. I walked in a bit before 9am and asked a female baker behind the counter about the Cronut; she replied in a snippy tone "I'm so annoyed with the whole Cronut thing. I guess people like them tho."

Um, great salesmanship there. You really made me want to come back and try the rest of the products you also don't believe in. This was my first time in the bake shop and your lack of enthusiasm for your own product was a bit disheartening.
author: Bryan Y.

description: This place was cool. I had some fresh fruit and oatmeal. You can't go wrong with a basic breakie and some fresh baked goods. Coffee was good. You can bus your own table. Or not.
author: Jillian E.

description:
Itrems Selected:
Almond Croissant
Chocolate Banana Bread Pudding
Cinnamon Brioche Swirl
Chocolate Chip and Almond Cookie
Raspberry and Mocha Macarons
Pecan Pie Bar

Slotted in the unenviable position of early breakfast on my last half-day in town I'd be lying if I claimed Fillmore Bakeshop to be anything more than a convenient curiosity en route from my hotel to b.patisserie yet with a friendly staff and comparatively low prices to the rest of San Francisco the small storefront actually managed a pair of delicious highs amidst otherwise mediocre offerings and air-pocketed macarons overloaded with sugary paste and far worse than those of many home cooks.  Obviously an 'everything to everyone' sort of place with French pastry lined up along favorites from the American Kitchen it should probably come as no surprise that items warm from the kitchen would prove amongst Fillmore's strongest and beginning there the croissant was a fairly good start with nature's subtlety replacing sticky frangipane amidst crispy curls and moving on to the brioche bun a similar crunch was found, though this time giving way to a springy buttered core liberally dressed in cinnamon sugar.  Saving cookies and 'pie' for later only to be underwhelmed in each it was last during my visit that my attention turned to the 'still-too-hot-too-eat' bread pudding and still my very favorite type of dessert no matter how 'simple' to prepare this particular version proved lovely - a big scoop fresh from the pan teaming with custard-laced old croissants, fresh bananas, and intense dark chocolate beneath a lightly toasted top.
author: Michael U.

description: Went here while in town based on a recent review I had read.   Parking is impossible of course.  Staff is friendly, the interior is very basic, but overall the baked goods were just okay,  nothing really special or memorable.
author: Jan K.

description:
I randomly walked into this bakery and bought a slice of blueberry pie and 4 different flavored macarons. Their macarons are pretty interesting. The meringue part is fluffier than usual and the fillings are creamy with the perfect level of sweetness. My favorite was the strawberry.

The blueberry pie was filled with lots of blueberries, but also had too much of the syrupy goo, which killed it for me. I wouldn't order this again.

The workers are friendly and work quickly to help customers. Seating is extremely limited, so it's best to take your baked goodies to-go.
author: Theresa C.

description:
What a cute little shop!  Their macaroons are gorgeous - the cookie is on the thicker side, but tasty.  And very reasonable at $1.95 a pop.

They also offer a wide selection of pastries (think croissants and pies and twists).

Solid establishment.  You know they bake their own stuff cuz you can see their open kitchen behind the counters.
author: Vicki C.

description:
It pains me to write a less than stellar review for this place because the owners were so nice. 

I only got macarons, so I can only comment on that. The macarons are big and beautiful (no matter how I rearrange those words, it still sounds funny... bear with me). There are so many bright, tantalizing colors and flavors. I got: rose, pistachio, and blood orange. The blood orange filling was really good. Pistachio was not bad.

Here's the problem: all of them have HUGE air pockets in them. The shells are completely hollow. That's unacceptable! A macaron is NOT supposed to have air pockets. (See my pictures for more information.) Take it from a macaron lover and baker. When a macaron has huge air pockets, the shell shatters into a million pieces when you bite into it, instead of delicately crumbling into your mouth. It's crispy and hollow, instead of slightly crisp on the outside and soft and a little cakey inside. Also, the macarons were a tad dry- they would benefit from maturing overnight to let the flavors settle.

I'll come back and try the croissants and other things, maybe they'll be better. The macarons were disappointing, though... I didn't think a professional bakery would have air pockets in all their macarons!!
author: Cathy S.

description:
Tried the apricot pie - a huge slice with soo much apricot filling in it. It was tangy and the crust was sweet so it was yummy!

Salted caramel macaron and honey lavender -- i personally didnt like the lavendar one it tasted like soap but the caramel one was delish.
author: Isabella L.

description:
(Blasting from a car by the bakery)
Wu-Tang Clan ain't nuthin to fu** with!  Wu-Tang Clan aint' nuthin to fu** with!

I head nodded my way in, and was greeted by a massive display of French Macarons, $1.95 a piece.  I don't want to be a mac snob, but I'm very specific about my macs.  They have to be the right size, taste like the flavor that it's actually labeled, the right amount of crunch and most importantly, the perfect amount of "chew". So when I reached the display case of macs, I noticed their macs were HUGE, at least 2 inches high.  Uh-oh.  I'm fighting 2 different feelings now.  I've never seen macs this size, and that already goes against one of my "mac-do's" criteria. On the other hand, they looked so volumptuous and interesting.   The first one that caught my eye was the coconut mac.  I'm a sucker for coconut.  SOLD.

How do I explain how perfect this mac was?  When I bit into it, there was a crunch.  Then air.  Then chewiness.  Then cream.  Then chewiness again.  Then bliss.  Yes, the size threw me off, but this mac was the red-headed step-child that won me over.  

I also tried Chocolate, Pistachio, Almond, and Vanilla.  The chocolate was excellent, as was the pistachio.  They both had the same consistency as the coconut mac.  Unfortunately, the almond and vanilla were overbaked, and crumbled to sand and rocks at first bite.  But I'm not docking stars for that.  (I've learned from over countless bakery visits that certain batches of pastries are a hit or miss daily.)

So dare I say I found my new fave mac spot?  I dare.

Fillmore Bakeshop ain't nuthin to fu** with!
author: Rho T.

description:
Highlights: 
- Cinnamon sugar cronuts are worth the early AM wait on a rainy Saturday, especially because they come out warm and fresh.

Improvements:
- Cronuts are only sold during a limited time in the AM beginning at 9am until they run out. 4 quantity maximum per person. 
- Only 2 flavors of cronuts when I went and they change each week. Chocolate Hazelnut was a bust, I would skip. Wish I came when they had lemon.
- Macarons are huge, but the texture and taking a bite out of that thing is not easy nor clean. Hollow and crumbly. Skip.

Tip: Rain or shine there is always a line on a Saturday morning. Everyone's got to get their hands on those cronuts!
author: Tracy T.

description:
It's a love/hate relationship working in the area that I do.... is it any wonder why I'm gaining weight??

Whenever I get a craving for sweets I have Sift, B Patisserie, Jane, Fraiche and Fillmore Bakeshop all within walking distance from me. AHHHHHHH!!!!!'

Most everything here is wonderful and the staff is always willing to help with making suggestions. I've tried a handful of things here already but my absolute favorites are the different types of cronuts they have and their lemon pound cake!

Helpful tip, cronuts come out after 9am, so getting there early to line up really doesn't matter. I came at 8am once to find this out. I then came back at 9:45a and there were about 10 parties in front of me totalling a 15 minute wait. Not bad.
author: amelia g.

description: The macaroons are gigantic and way too sweet. BUT I swear this place makes the best cherry pie I have ever had. And I have had a lot of cherry pie in my life.
author: stephanie l.

description:
5 stars solely based on taste. They have the best macarons and nut bars (they're like mini pecan pie bars..don't know the official name). Haven't tried their pastries or cakes, but I'm sure they're just as delicious.

However, they seem to sell out of a lot of their desserts by mid afternoon, or maybe I'm just unlucky at the times I do go. I came in about 130 pm and they were out of cronuts and macarons, and I was really disappointed. They're also on the pricier side, but I'm willing to pay as long as the desserts are ACTUALLY there lol. Maybe I need to come earlier or call ahead to see what they have that day..
author: Cristina L.

description:
BEWARE of purchasing a Gilt City voucher or any voucher for this establishment!!

I called Fillmore bakeshop to try to redeem my voucher for a dozen D's Nutz and they told me that their orders are full and not able to honor my voucher. They told me to call Gilt City to take care of it, which I did, and it looks like Gilt City is looking into this matter.

 Ok...why promote yourself on deal site if you're not able to fulfill your end of the bargain. Bad business practices. 

I don't care if you guys have "cronuts" and if they're delicious. This experience has left a nasty taste in my mouth.
author: Valerie P.

description: Yelp it and cronuts magically appear.  Staying right around the corner from Fillmore Bakeshop, I happened upon their listing on Yelp and saw that they served cinnamon sugar cronuts, aka, D's Nutz, here on Thursday and Friday mornings.  The b/f and I sauntered over on a recent Friday morning, arriving at 8:00am, an hour too early to get our share.  We came back an hour later and I had my first Fillmore cronut with a soy cappuccino:  heavenly!  The cronut was light, with flaky layers just like a croissant, and the cinnamon sugar dusting was just right.  I shared a bite with the b/f and then had to get another one-so good!  The shop wasn't too busy, but business was steady, with many customers there to get there cronut fix, too.  We came back on Saturday morning so the b/f could get an almond croissant and I had a pretzel, which was also just right.  Saturday mornings is when the Bakeshop offers special flavors of cronuts and there was a line out the door at 8:30am for the 9:00am batches.  We bypassed that line, though, and got the other items we wanted--I'd gotten my cronut fill the day before.  This is the place to go, just like Yelp said, not just for cronuts, but for many other delicious baked goods.
author: Terri C.

description:
Maybe it's because I'm living vicariously through the father/daughter team (and hoping my baby girl grows up with strong forearms), but Fillmore Bakeshop is hands-down one of my favorite neighborhood bakeries.

The macarons are phenomenal. They're a little unconventional in the sense that they're the size of baseballs, but that's perfectly fine with me. I haven't met a flavor yet that I didn't like. My go-to gift these days is a box of 6 macarons, which they'll pack in a nice little box for you.

The other baked goods are delicious, too. We had some of the shortbread cookies for brunch the other day, and they were excellent. One of them was an orange-scented shortbread with just the right amount of orange.

For baby's baptism, we ordered the princess cake, and it was a huge hit. Creamy and marzipan-y, and delicious. Run, don't walk.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Mmmm... the cronut craze has finally made it's way over to San Francisco. Unfortunately, I didn't get the message that they start selling at 9am, so I showed up at 7am :) The rest of the crowd started showing up around 8.  So we lined up, and were able to get our cronuts by 8:45am. 

And delicious and tasty they were!! A nice balance of cinnamon and sugar, with the fluffiness of a croissant.  Although, would I wait an hour again for these bad boys? Probably not. I'll settle with a kouign amann elsewhere, or just wait for this trend to die down and get them when I don't need to wait an hour again.

I need to come back to this place though and try their other goodies :)
author: Stephanie L.

description: Do not go to another bakery in SF! You'll be sorry you missed this one. The croissants, the bear claws, the cookies, the breads, Oh my! The best of the best! And Elena, the co-owner with her Dad, knows how to deliver customer service. Thank you Elena from your new San Jose BFFS.
author: Mary Anne B.

description:
We came for a cake but instead we left with a bundle of macaroons!!!! 

O my goodness!!! Fat kid dreams have been fulfilled!!! They had about 8 flavors to pick from. Each looking better than the next. From lavender honey, rose, irish coffee, coffee, hazelnut, and soooo much more!!! 

Each bite was full of popping o hell yes flavor! The outer shell was flakey and the center was ewy gooey and yummo!! Cream was never too over powering. Really I think I found a competitor for Miete. But here is the kicker that might push it ahead of the game...they are BIGGER than Miete and CHEAPER!!! They go for $1.95 each and are about twice the size of the norm. I counted a three biter... 

O MY!!! No way I am not coming back to try the other flavors. And maybe next time we will not be dummy and not pre-order the cake!
author: Michelle I.

description:
The peach pie is so wonderful, I had it three times in three weeks!

I've enjoyed other things, too, but that peach pie . . . 

Be sure to check out the photos on the wall.  The owner's dad was HOT back in the day!!!
author: Bay G.

description:
Protip: Come early, it will get packed before you know it

What to get: Cronuts. They were divine to say the least. Tasty and flaky just like a croissant with the shape of a donut. I was lucky to try both of them and they were both good. If you have been looking for a donut wtih custard inside, the kronut with a custard filling does a good job as a parallel representation. The cinnamon sugar cronut was also very tasty reminiscent of a good sugar donut. The texture of the cronut was really nice, not too heavily deep fried and the layers and layers you'd find in a croissant are well made inside each kronut. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NOTE: they limit you to 4 PER PERSON AND THEY ONLY SERVE IT ON SATURDAYS between 9 and 10 am!*
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Macarons: The macarons weren't spectacular for me. The the outside layer was too airy and the filling was too creamy. The flavor was there but the nice contrast between layers wasn't particularly impressive. Not bad and not spectacular but still decent.

Apple Danish: The apple danish was delicious. From the moment I set my eyes on them, the apples looked remarkably fresh and the danish very nice, so I took a chance on them. The apples had a nice bite to them to contrast the soft texture of the pastry. The pastry was nice and flaky and the gooey apple center was a cherry on top. If you are into apple danishes, try it out!

Recommend: Cronut/Kronut, both custard filled and cinnamon sugar, and the apple danish.
author: Dylan T.

description:
The colorful macarons on display caught my mom's eye as we were walking back from Fraiche, and after a quick Yelp consultation, we decided to wander in and check things out. And, while I've always had some notion that macarons were pricy, $1.95 each exceeded even my expectations. 

Nevertheless, being there already, and wanting to at least try it before knocking it, we nabbed a pistachio and chocolate hazelnut to try. The pistachio was lacking in any flavor other than sweet, with an almost imperceptible pistachio flavor. The chocolate hazelnut, on the other hand, was much tastier, and, surprisingly, less sweet. Both had those nice crunchy shells one expects from macarons, though the dough inside was ever-so-slightly chewy, which was somewhat unexpected (but not particularly bad either).

When it comes down to it though, neither blew me away, and certainly not to the point of a $2 markup, especially when I can get much tastier, flavor bang for buck, baked goods elsewhere.
author: Johnny W.

description: We recently received a gift of a dozen assorted cookies from this shop. They were very, very delicious. We will definitely make this a favorite!
author: J C.

description: The best peach pie in town,  also excellent donut.
author: Ed Y.

description:
I was working in Pacific Heights when this bakery opened. A father daughter owned bakery. The father used to teach pastry school, so he is top of the line. The cakes, pies, cookies, croissants, everything is amazing delicious!  They even have quiche. Their holiday fair: the Stollen holiday bread is hands down the most delicious sweet delight ever: marinated dried fruits/nuts in alcohol for months before baking. It comes wrapped in holiday bows!  Great gift with compliments every time.  They make many other holiday sweets that are amazing.  
People have found them and caught on to their greatness. So now the prices have gone up big time and the portions are smaller. That is why the 4 stars instead of 5 stars.  
I just ordered my Thanksgiving boysenberry pie and was told the size is now smaller and the price $27.  Wow.  I still ordered it because it is one day a year to splurge and enjoy comforts of good eating. The cost of the Stollen has gone up big time over the years too. I wonder what it is this year.  Instead of given a loaf to all the neighbors this year, I will probably just buy one for my father.
author: Karen J.

description: Last night I made a mental note to drive over here after my errand this morning.  I've missed several opportunities already to purchase the cronut.   So I walked in around 9:30am holding my breath and crossing my fingers.  Looked into the display case and eyed a stack.  YES!  I took a heavy sigh.  Finally.  I bought three.   Still warm in the box.  I stepped on the gas petal and rushed home keeping an eye on the speedo.  Got home and ran upstairs and opened up the box.  Put the cronut on a plate, made a cup of coffee and enjoyed one bite at a time.  Flaky, warm, sugary, and everything nice.  What a great morning treat.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I'm a big macaroon fan. So when I saw that there was a place that sold them in the filmore I went to this bakery and tried them out. Let me tell you THEY WERE TERRIBLE! Blah, worst I've had in my life! They were dry and when you were chewing it, it would become a nasty blob in your mouth! It wasn't soft and airy like a real macaroon! Boo 

I'm still giving this place three stars cause the staff is extremely friendly and I'm sure their other stuffs good.... Try something else, not the French macaroons! Ew
author: Nathalie B.

description: Got a $27 pumpkin pie from these folks for Thanksgiving, and wow, was that a HUGE mistake. Crust had no taste whatsoever and was soggy. The pumpkin filling maybe had a bit of taste but was basically only texture - and the texture was pasty not firm. What a waste of money and time. You would think these people would put some work into a $27 pie. But judging from the results, it's clear they don't care because if they did, someone would have tasted it and realized there was nothing there at all. They should be ashamed of themselves for passing off such crappy baked goods off as something worth paying money for.
author: Steve L.

description:
Cronuts are out of this world. Flaky and warm croissant/donut, doesn't get much better than that. 
The workers here are friendly and provide quick service. Their bakery is open so it is cool to see what they are making! Cronut price is a little steep- $2.75. But worth every bite.
author: Alisha K.

description:
I have to say, I'm fairly new to the macaron scene. There are some veterans in the game of confectioneries who knows macarons more than their own mothers. There is no perfect macaron, it's like the quest for the holy grail, but one of the flavors at Fillmore Bakeshop is nearly flawless!

First take a look at my pictures and drool:
http://media3.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/i3UyekBZIJLAZ-bEI6nj1g/l
and
http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/InU_nEdg488yp1tuYnLnfg/l

The macarons here are larger than the ones I've had before at other bakeries. That's a bonus! They're $1.95 each.

Now lets summarize the flavors:

-Chocolate - Chocolatey is the only word I can think of for this. Scrumptious gooey chocolate.

-Pistachio - Always a favorite no matter what bakery. Nutty great flavors, not too sweet, addictive.

-Rose - I don't necessarily like tasting flowers, never been a fan of rose flavored products. But it's good enough for a recommendation here.

-Mango - Tropical and sweet, however a bit too sweet for me.

-Lemon - I noticed this flavor's quantity was running low, now I see why. Probably the best tasting macaron that has touched my tongue! Zesty and delicious. The cream is a perfect blend of sweet, lemony, and good gracious bodacious flavor! I've been craving it everyday.

Overall, I probably prefer the outside cookie of the macaron at Paulettes, but the filling here is just dream cream! One of the best.

The staff here is also super super friendly and helpful. Do yourself a sweet favor next time you're in SF, surrender to these macarons.
author: Minh D.

description:
I can't compare this place to any other bakery...Because I've never been to another one.

My friends and I came here because I wanted to try macarons. I tried the vanilla macaron, my friend had a honey lavender macaron. NEVER get the honey lavendar macaron unless you like eating soap. However, as for the vanilla macaron, the cookie portion was rather thick; the whole macaron seemed out of proportion.

Price to taste, this place isn't worth it.
author: Bonita K.

description:
We kinda just stumbled upon this place looking for coffee one morning. Boy, I'm glad we did!

Their macarons are just meh to me. I was more excited to try their cronuts. We tried both coffee crunch and cinnamon sugar flavors. Dammnnn. The coffee crunch one was so good, it was gone in 5 seconds! I like their cronut much better than Dominque Ansel's.  

I mean, how are you going to beat out the originator?!
author: Kathryn N.

description:
This review is only for the macarons. Everyone raved about them on yelp so I had to try them. I was having brunch somewhere down the street so I was happy we could stop by and grab macarons before heading home. I got there around 4 PM on a Sunday and the bakery had barely any goods left. They had 6 macaron flavors, so I got one of each. The macarons are fairly small and they cost 1.95. I guess your in SF so expect inflated prices. 

For 1.95 I was expecting amazingness to happen in my mouth. When I got home and finally bit into one, I realized 1.95 had gone down the drain. These macarons are terrible! For the price you pay for Filmore you can go to Chantal Guillon or Miette and get amazing macarons for 1.75-1.80. The macarons here are terrible. They crack and break upon biting. They over whipped the meringue and the fillings were not premium at all. 

Although, I do have to say service was very pleasant and nice.
author: Stacey L.

description:
I'm writing a review only for their cronut and macarons, as I have yet to try anything else from them. Unfortunately, I had no idea they only sell their fancy cronuts on Saturdays, so I went in on Friday thinking I was going to get one.

I discovered they DO sell sugar coated cronuts (aka D's Nutz) everyday, so I ended up just getting one of those. The cronut was good, but not great. It might be because it's so plain, so I'll have to come back for a fancy one some other time. 

I also got a Mocha Macaron, as many other reviews said their macarons are amazing. I was sadly disappointed by it. It was a very strange texture, unlike other macarons I've tasted before. 

I would actually recommend heading to La Boulange de Pine instead (which is right down the street) if you're there on a weekday. Though, I'm definitely going to give Fillmore Bakeshop another shot soon!
author: Vandy P.

description: Found this bakery on our recent trip to San Fran!! I feel like I ordered one of everything! So good!!! Best blondie I have had in a long time!!!! So amazing!! I cannot wait to go back to this yummy bakery in November.
author: Karen T.

description: This place is the shit. My brother saw it on yelp so decided to try it. Did not disappoint. Had the poppyseed Danish- amazinggggg. Also ordered French macarons and assorted Thanksgiving cookies. Those gingery cookies were perfect. Loved it, going back right now.
author: Christina R.

description: Every pastry, cookie and cake I have ever had at Fillmore Bakeshop has been perfect. They have the best chocolate chip cookies in the world. And the new Unicorn Cakes are incredible - unique, creative, and of course, delicious.
author: Emily M.

description:
Everything looks good but it has no finesse and punch to it.
Rule of thumb is do not go into bakery stores 5 minute before it closed.

No customer service. No more baked goods. With limited baked goods, they still charge full priced.

Very disappointed with this place.
author: Calvary D.

description:
Came here after eating at the Woodhouse Fish Company because of their macaroons.  We were pretty full so didn't have them right away after we bought them.  But it was pretty good, a little too sweet for my liking, but good nonetheless.  Plus, I think they were pretty creative with their flavors.  I got the raspberry, salted caramel, rose and honey lavender flavors.  The outside was very light and sorta crispy, just the right amount where it's the perfect pastry.  The inside filling was creamy, definitely caught me off guard but mmm it was good.  I just wish I had a cup of joe to complement the macarons and I think it would've been the perfect pair. 

Also, customer service was excellent.  So, what happened when we first got there was this lady was really rude after coming to the conclusion that they were out of a lot of things that she wanted.  Understandable because there were only three people working and this was a pretty small bakery.  But she just went off on the cashier, and the cashier (working at Starbucks all these years and said he's been through worse) smiled through it and kept up with his end.  All I can say is, I'm not sure if I could've kept it in like he did, which explains why I wouldn't do well in customer service.  He also didn't let that incident ruin his day or the rest of his customers, and was a delight helping us with our orders.  So, props to him!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
A father-daughter bakeshop putting their stamp not only in the Fillmore District but in San Francisco. This story in the San Francisco Chronicle details their background and how their lovely shop on Bush and Fillmore came to be.

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/02/18/DDMT1HDIBO.DTL

My gf and I have been there twice to sample their macarons (Champagne Chocolate is my fav), a slice of their Princess Cake (my gf loves it), their popular Hot Cross Buns (sadly only available until Easter), and their crown jewel Banana Chocolate Bread Pudding (my new favorite place for my all-time favorite dessert).

The owners are so friendly and burst with enthusiasm and pride over what they make. It's been a joy visiting their store and we hope to go there many more times. I still have to try Elena's other bread pudding flavors of course :D
author: Randy T.

description:
Had the privilege of stopping by this lovely bakeshop for a midday sweet stop.  A very well lit and organized shop that is family run, nice variety of baked pastries, cakes, french macaroons.  

I was told that this bakery is 6 months new under new management and you can see the hard work and effort.  Two small tables with chairs let you relax and watch Fillmore life pass by.  I'd suggest having another table or perhaps sidewalk tables if allowed.

The photos are of the caramel macaroon on the left and guava on the right. 

On a positive note, we (3 of us) shared a table with a single and had a really great conversation over coffee and sweets!
author: Randall F.

description:
This bakeshop is the bomb! They serve up delicious pastries like peach pie, a variety of croissants and something called kronuts. I sampled the kronuts and OMG they are so delectable. Kronuts are fried and dipped in a cinnamon and sugar coating. If I did not have to wait 30 minutes for a fresh batch, I would have ordered a box of kronuts.

They have so many mouth watering pastries to choose from but I especially like their almond croissant. Their pastries are baked fresh and the prices are reasonable. Great place to drop in on a Saturday morning. They also serve coffee and other specialty coffee drinks like mocha. There is only 1 small table inside for dining so expect to take your order to go. Don't be surprised if you see a line out the door...they are that good.
author: Natalie S.

description: First let me start by saying I have only posted a review on Yelp two other times but I feel so compelled to share my experience with Fillmore Bakeshop that it is the first thing I did the morning after our event. For the last 4 months we have been planning our parent's 50th Golden Anniversary dinner which we held in the exact same room they celebrated their union 50 years ago (SF Presidio Officer's Club). After some miscommunication on who would handle the cake, I was frantic trying to find someone who could create a smaller version of their wedding cake based on a picture. I called the Fillmore Bakeshop and explained my story and Elena was so pleasant and very willing to help even at the last minute. I picked up the cake yesterday and all I can say is it brought my Mom to tears. The cake not only looked almost identical with all the intricate detailing and lace work but it tasted AMAZING!!! Thank you, Fillmore Bakeshop for making the evening so memorable!!! Posting pictures so I hope they match up with this review.
author: Michelle L.

description: Wonderful and beautiful cake and the taste is delicious! Gotta love it! Thanks for picking up the cake Serge!
author: Danny H.

description: I picked up a few things the other week and one of them was the cronut and thought it was ok.  I picked up a custard crossiant, I believe, and it was not memorable to me.  My friends showed me pics of cronuts they picked up from this place and it didn't look like the ones I got. Maybe they only bake certain ones on certain days?  I just thought it was okay.  Maybe I'll give them another try one day.
author: James L.

description:
My gym and this bakery are equidistant from my apartment. I'll let you guess which one I've been visiting more often.

The pastries are unreal. I daren't utter the word 'boysenberry' (it's one of my least favourite words) but I'll be damned if I won't eat it in the form of scrumptious, gooey and sinful bread pudding. Bread pudding at Fillmore is co-founder Elena's specialty and part of a flavour rotation that will lure you in for multiple visits. So far I've tried the berry and apple versions and they're everything I lust for in a dessert. When I think back to all the dessert menus I've scanned, this has 

Macarons here come in flavours I've never seen before - chocolate mint (a must), saffron, raspberry, lemon, and the requisite pistachio and rose. The colourful display case is a real sight to behold, and you'll have a hard time deciding which confectioneries to splurge on. If you're a fan of fondant and expertly crafted cakes in intricate designs, they have heaps of them and I'm fairly certain they take custom orders. Personally I prefer to stare longingly at the slightly less sweet options in the case on the right - pain au chocolat, almond croissants, raisin breads and all sorts of puffy delights. 

Noshing on anything baked in this lovely new addition to (Lower) Pacific Heights is well worth the extra time on the rotating step mill (my torture device of choice).
author: Kat F.

description: Really cute local bakeshop. Family style treats and family style service. Perfect break spot from a long shopping stint to rest your weary feet. I tried the meringue and a rainbow sprinkle cookie with an orange juice. Super affordable and delicious. Shopping was able to be continued. Disaster averted. Bliss attained.
author: Patricia L.

description:
They're baking up a storm at the new family owned Fillmore Bakeshop: whole cakes, cake slices, cookies, small croissants, cupcakes, pies, tarts, fruit danish and more.  I spotted some items that looked similar to what Patisserie Delanghe (the previous occupant and a better bakery) carried, including mini éclairs, lacy Florentine cookies and Princess cake. The cupcake of the day idea is charming and they had all sorts of Giants inspired items a little while back. Coffee and other beverages are available.

* Brioche roll - rather small round roll, not that buttery, decent texture, average 
* Almond biscotti - very hard and crunchy with hazelnuts and almonds, I didn't like the slight anise flavor, the texture seemed too hard (even though I like very crunchy biscotti)

The interior hasn't changed much since the Delanghe days.  Décor is sparse/minimal but they have nicer signs now.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I live walking distance to this cute small bakeshop and it's a nice new option compared to Peets and Starbucks. 

I'm a fan of some of their pastries like the cronut but I'm not so much a fan of their macarons. 
They're pretty inconsistent and a lot of the time poofy (underfolded), crunchy and dry but sometimes are o-k. 

Overall a nice friendly place to stop by to grab a quick pastry and coffee.
author: Jesse K.

description:
(See pretty pics)

I love pastries and bakery. They always steal my heart and in return give me delightful happiness.

I have walked by this place a lot of times but they were always closed. Tonight I was walking by and surprisingly the bright lights shining through the street. I was so ecstatic and ran across the street to find out their very pretty, colourful and delicious pastries, cookies, meringues, macaroons, biscotti, crossiants and whole fancy cakes.

Found out they just reopened recently as a father and daughter's shop, taking over from previous owner's retirement, and had renovated the whole place.

The pecan bun and brioche bun were tasty, the biscotti was exotic with some herb taste to it, the meringues were so airy and I got a collection of different coloured and tasted ones, from pumpkin, pistachio, chocolate, ginger, coffee, etc etc.

They also have different sliced desserts and an individual coffee making machine on hand. A few tables now make the place a perfect afternoon enjoying the city after lunch, or simply picking up some sweets for your later after dinner dreamy ending.

I am glad we now once again have a lovely and sugary shop on Fillmore.
author: T L.

description:
The macaroons are to die for.
They are a great size for a considerable price.

They are palm size which is CRAZY seeing others that are like thumb size for the same price!
author: Anthony R.

description: So I haven't actually been to the actual bakery so this review is really based upon the product which I had at a company function.  CRONUT!!!!!  I haven't had one before despite hearing about it from various ppl in NY.  All I can say is that they were amazing.  Definitely a good benchmark for being my first one!
author: Spencer Q.

description:
This bakery is super duper cute and family-owned.  I get drawn in by the brightly colored macarons.  Not only are they beautiful, but they're huge!  I think they must be the biggest macarons I've seen in any bakery in the city (I'm definitely not counting the monstrous macarons at Bouchon).

But, while the macarons are big and probably most worth the money, they're not my favorite macarons.  They're a little too crumbly for my taste.  I like to take a bite out of my macarons and not have them fall apart all over the place.  It's just my personal preference as I'm sure some people prefer the crumbly macarons, but I prefer mine a little bit more chewy.
author: Kris L.

description:
I should have never walked in.. I was curious to see what their chocolate chip cookies tasted like as I love chocolate chip cookies and never pass a bakery without trying one. At first glance, it looked a bit plain and sorta flat. I left the bakery and I was so surprised by how moist and chewy it was. I had to go back and buy some more! On my second trip to the bakery, I bought the macaroons, a slice of peach pie and the consistency and quality is equal to the chocolate chip cookies.They are also selling cronuts on Saturdays only!!! They advise to get their by 8 a.m. Last weekend, they sold over 700 cronuts in matter of 20 minutes!
The service is exceptional as well, very authentic and genuine. (Prices are very reasonable, $1.50 for the cookie)! I'm starting to work out so I can go back weekly!
author: Suzie Y.

description:
S'more please.

Getting older comes with the right to have as much childhood indulgences you please. This includes the best thing about camping.

Now available in bar form with a graham base topped with gooey chocolate and marshmallow. Let your inner child scream.

Mine did and only wished the bar was a bit larger. Great taste. Fair $3 cost.

Indulge away.
author: Jason B.

description:
JUST OPENED!!!

The last pastry shop that was on this corner was amazing, so pretty big shoes to fill by Bakeshop! Luckily they matched up very well. 

The chocolate ganache cookies are nice (not too sweet, but very chocolaty). A very tasty Napoleon lasted about 10 seconds after my first bite...enough said.

The new owners are a father and daughter and seem very nice, its a good place to give a try.
author: Chirag V.

description:
I recently stumbled upon The Fillmore Bakeshop and couldn't be happier!   The macaroons were phenomenal and the service was outstanding too.  I was helped by a lovely brunette named Maddy who explained how they were made and even showed us some of the neat tools they use to make cookies.  

Looking forward to returning for the princess cake, which I was told is equally as good.   So much for those New Years resolutions!!
author: David H.

description: This place was pretty busy the morning my boyfriend and I came in which can only mean that people like this place. They have a lot of different breakfast items that you can choose from which made it harder to me to pick something. We ended up ordering coffee and a raspberry danish. I only wished we ordered more. We were fighting for the danish after we took our first bites. Love this place and will be back in the future!
author: Thy T.

description: amazing collection of baked goodies like the florentine which is an almond brittle on chocolate , croissants, cakes and more . I highly recommend their chocolate mousse cake. I also have had their cappuccino which isn't great. Too frothy !
author: Priyanka P.

description:
I'll be honest, I came here for their 'formally known as cronuts' treats. Nothing beats a cronut straight out from the fryer still warm and crispy. I had the custard filled version and it was delicious. I also go some parisian macaroons, which were the biggest I've ever seen so definitely worth the price.

I will definitely need to come back for more cronuts, but next time I want to try their other baked goods too.
author: Stephanie K.

description: The boysenberry pie is delicious! Stuffed with a loads of filling and crisp pastry. Bought some chocolates too - quite pricey but if they're as good as the pie they'll be worth it.
author: Felicity B.

description:
I wish they'd have a location in my North Beach/Russian Hill....

I love most of their pastries and D's nutz (cronut).  Princess cake is really magnificent.
Everything is good but 1 star deducted on the macarons.  I bought 1 of each flavor a few weeks ago and they were interesting.  Which is fine, but I think I was expecting the traditional kind.

Their staff is warm, friendly in person and through Facebook too!  I love how they got the entire community involved to vote for what is now known as "D's Nutz" rather than "dossiant" or "cronut."  All very fun and engaging!
author: May W.

description:
Oh.....

My.......

Heaven......

It's Nirvana in a little colored morsel!  It's all about the Macaron's for me!  Fillmore has made me very, very, happy - and I've never even been there!

So I get a text Friday night from a friend.  She has a box for me.  She has a box filled with colorful goodies for me.  It's for me - and it's from Fillmore!!!

This review is only for the macarons, as I've not tried anything else from here (but boy do I want to!)

Yellow macarons
Orange macarons
Green macarons
Vanilla macarons
Chocolate macarons

All so wonderfully good!  Beautifully rounded meringue tops, perfectly raised from their feet.  The fillings not too sweet or overpowering.  Hard to say, but chocolate is winning (and I'm usually a fan of just vanilla or lavender).

It just amazes me how a bakery in San Francisco can produce a product that is so temperamental to humidity.  On my one and only attempt to make macarons - which were successful save for overbeating the whites - I planned my baking a week ahead for a low-humidity day and enough time to age the whites.  Too much fru-fru planning for me.  I'll stick to the macarons that arrive in boxes!

Thank you Fillmore for somehow being responsible for that box landing up in my hands.  (Can the next box have the chocolate torte? lol)
author: Linda L.

description:
One of my favorite bakeries in SF!  A charming setting with very nice people, always greeting me with a smile.  I love their huge selection of pastries in the morning, from standard croissants, raise swirls, bear claws, to more inventive items like cronuts (oft-cited in other reviews), pastries with lots of poppy seeds and hazelnut, etc..  This place is not as fancy and stylish as some of the other bakeries getting more attention in the city (such as B Patisserie & Le Marais), but I like their more down-to-earth feel and less rich nature of their baked goods (with the exception of those cronuts which are very rich).  Some of the negative reviews here mention the macaroons, which I've never had there but are (in my opinion) a total fad anyway and should not be the measure for assessing bakery quality.  Also someone mentioned that they had very little offering before closing -- well duh!  that's actually a good sign for a bakery because you know everything is freshly made in the morning!

Anyway it's hard to resist perhaps more hip and happening places down the street like (the now mega-chain) Le Boulange, or Jane, but I am happy to get my coffee and baked good here to avoid the crowds (and the strollers!).  Support this mom and pop joint!
author: Ray H.

description:
I was grabbing coffee with a friend in the neighborhood and was in the mood for a good afternoon macaron.  

This place more than exceeded my expectations as they had a wide variety of macarons, cakes and pastries.  They had some of the more traditional flavors (chocolate, vanilla, strawberry), but also some more interesting varieties such as honey lavender, salted caramel, blackberry and pistachio.  Not only were these $2 gems beautiful (including some great "tie-dye" like effects on some of the flavors), but they taste absolutely divine and are very fresh.  You can even see some of the workers preparing other kinds of pastries on the tables behind the counter!  

The service was great as the staff was friendly and provided the appropriate care, but also kept things moving so that everyone in line got their sweets quickly.  This is a must if you are in the neighborhood and looking for a great bakery!...or just for some pure macaron joy!
author: Maria K.

description: I wasn't here for the D'Nutz, new word for Cronuts.  I'm here for the macaroons, it's crunchy and quite puffy, not as how I would like them.  I'm looking for the almond flour. The taste was flavorful.  I couldn't help but noticed the cherry pie, lots of cherries, real looking cherries, spilling out of the crust getting my attention, and telling me "choose me, choose me," so I did.  I had to get out of there, all the pastries were all screaming, "choose me."  Can't wait to go back and try everything. The pie was really good, not too sweet, just the right tartness.  Apparently they make fresh pies depending on whatever is delivered on Tuesday.  Can't wait to see what pies are available next week.
author: Helen L.

description: I ordered the Chocolate Salted Caramel cake for a friend's birthday.  I placed the order on Friday and picked it up Sunday morning.  The cake was incredible!  So delicious.  I even heard a few "this is the best cake I've ever had".  Highly recommend.  Did not disappoint.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Can't believe I haven't written a review yet.  I bought a croquembouche here back in August and it was perfect!  Delicious and beautiful.

It's nice to have another french style bakery in San Francisco that is not only good but reasonably priced.
author: Gina C.

description:
Where to find your weekend afternoon treat in Fillmore? Make sure you stop by at this bakery. I've tried their Ham & Cheese (my fave), morning buns and raisin danishes...all wonderful and guaranteed to make you come back for more. If you're like me, order some to go for the next morning, but sometimes, they end up disappearing on the way home :-)
PS- Gotta try their macarons next
author: Arissa C.

description:
Visited here again this weekend.  Had their wild blueberry bread pudding - it was great!  

A couple weeks ago, I was there and heard a patron remark that their bread pudding was better than Tartine's.  Coincidentally, that weekend I was taking Tartine's bread pudding to a friend who lives down the peninsula.  So I grabbed an order of bread pudding too.  I was sneaky and didn't tell my friend which was which - and she liked Fillmore's better!  Of course, banana and chocolate vs. stone fruit bread pudding.  It's almost no contest....
author: Heather C.

description: My first review. Amazing bakery. Cronut, blueberry Danish, and chocolate croissant aka amazing. Wish I had more time and calories to spare. Every time I come to San Francisco this will be a regular stop.
author: Mike V.

description: Best pastries and pies in the city! Rivals the best danishes you could find in Paris. The boysenberry pie is to die for.... I can never eat supermarket pies again. My only complaints are that the cronuts run out too quickly (because they are so delicious) and my hips don't forgive me after eating a second serving.
author: Claire F.

description: Princess cake recommended. The light sponge, cream, jam, and marzipan was memorable and craveable. I look forward to trying other offerings at this non-pretentious and welcoming bakery.
author: Alicia L.

description:
I read so many good things about the Macarons at the Fillmore Bakeshop and decided to give it a try.  I was so excited by the fluffy colorful Macarons that was so much bigger than the ones I usually get.  My friend and I both bought half a dozen and we were ready to dig in.  Unfortunately, after our first bite of the Macaron were not at all chewy but the outer layer just crunched down due to a huge air bubble in the cookie.  I was very disappointed and so was my friend. Yes, it did taste good but it did not have that savory chewy feeling a Macaron should have. At first I thought it was just their style but later on I realized that was not the case.

Since my boyfriend and I both really like Macarons I decided to take him there just so he can try.  After learning my lesson, I only got one blackberry Macaron and expected it to crunch and collapse like last time but to my surprise this one was perfect.  It was chewy and delicious just like a Macaron should be.  My boyfriend also had one that was chewy but the other one just crunched down and collapsed.  

Fair warning I would say that Fillmore Bakery's Macarons are good but they are not all consistent, if you enjoy both the crunchy shell then it is for you, if not then you can try your luck.  I've also tried there Halloween Cookies and they were nice, buttery, and delicious :D !  Next time when I go, I'm going to try their pretty cakes!
author: Stephanie L.

description: I only had the cookies so will update when I return and try something else.   As far as the cookies go they were good BUT I prefer chewy cookies and their cookies were pretty crispy. Also, they really like to put nuts in their cookies. So it's just a matter of preference! I haven't tried anything else there yet, but they look delicious!
author: Alison H.

description: In a world of chain stores, the Fillmore Bakeshop is an oasis.  The ladies who were working there were very nice and made me feel at home.  As I sipped my coffee and enjoyed an éclair, I watched people stop in and browse the many delicious treats.  They had really fun decorations including some seriously wicked Halloween window art.  If I lived nearby, I'd make this a regular haunt.  If you are visiting near Japantown like me, I'd go out of my way to visit.
author: Joshua W.

description: Bread pudding - divine and not too sweet. **Getting it warm and fresh out of the oven on a cold and dreary SF day is a must.**  Fine fruity danishes.  Macaroons - pleasingly plump with lavender, coconut, and mocha cream.
author: Peg S.

description: I ordered the chocolate hazelnut cake for my friends birthday. I was absolutely surprised and impressed at how beautifully decorated it was.  I didn't have time to try other goodies but I am looking forward to going back!
author: Lanae S.

description: I was surprised to come in during the afternoon and see some of their cronuts (called "D's Nutz" here) still available, so I had to give them a try. They were perfectly dusted with cinnamon sugar and delicious with every bite. I'd eat these over regular donuts any day!
author: Jen P.

description:
Finally got a chance to try the cronuts.  Salted Carmel and Custard were the specialty flavors for the weekend (flavor changes every week, check their Facebook page for the weekly flavor).

Absolutely amazing.  LOVED the Salted Carmel.  Moist, light, flaky, sweet and salty.  Delicious.  The custard filled was also very good.

They only sell specialty cronuts on Saturdays from 9-10am.  I got there at 8:40am and had my cronut by 9am, about a 20 min wait, not bad.  The cronuts are made to order (aka are freshly made so they are still warm when you get them).  This is a must try.

Their other pastries are good too.  My favorite is the bread pudding.  It's costs about $3 and its a huge slice that can feed 2 people. 

I only wish they sold the specialty cronuts one day during the work week (Friday 8-9am???)  This would be a huge hit to bring for coworkers.
author: Shelly W.

description:
Items in my bag for the day: sugar and cinnamon cronuts, strawberry custard filled danish, ham and cheese croissant, and a chocolate croissant.

All I actually had was the cronut - of course I purchased the per person max of four! Wondering what all the rave was and not too willing to go to NYC, here they were down the block from my rental unit. Let me tell you, they were as good as described by fellow yelpers. Because I have not had any before this to compare, this got two forks up! Warm, tender, but crisp on the outside with just the right amount of cinammon and sugar - layer after flaky layer. I wish they had a custard filled cronut that day, but that just gives me another excuse to visit San Francisco!

BTW, my family of three children and a husband raved about the other items we purchased that morning. We came about 8:30 a.m. for fear they would run out of the cronut.
author: Eleanor C.

description:
This place is my go2 4:
It's Amy's turn to bring dessert.
Somebody is sad.  They need macaroons.
Someone is turning 21.  They need, you guessed it!  Chocolates.
I don't know what to bring to someone for some reason.
I'd like to buy my boyfriend chocolates and put them in a heart shaped box made out of chocolate for Valentine's Day.
I'm on Fillmore, want a cup of coffee and want someone to be nice to me.
Princess cake!!!!!!

I can't speak to all of the pastries (they're not really my thing), but the croissant I had here was great!  The macaroons and chocolates are both great...and they are always nice to me here.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: Stopped in here for a couple cronuts and a few macarons. The macarons were definitely top notch, but the cronuts were not the best I've had.  All in all a nice bakery with a decent selection of different baked goods, but not worth a 5star for me based on price/quality.  In a perfect world, we would judge on quality alone.
author: Ben K.

description:
Came here after being left hanging by the "boulange" style pastries at Starbucks. 
I had one of the cronuts, the almond croissant and the morning bun. The cronut was outstanding. I liken it to a beignet in the shape of a donut. The almond croissant was yummy...albeit the almond paste was very different from what you normally get: It was fluffier and less heavy. Sadly the morning bun was a disappointment. It was not quite as fresh as I would like it...hopefully a one off. The people selling in this bakeshop are super nice and excited about their products. I like that and I will be back to sample more of their yummy deliciousness!
author: Conny F.

description:
I was walking along Fillmore Street, minding my own business, when I passed by this little bakery. I almost kept walking until I saw this GORGEOUS Easter display that was being set-up. Chocolate bunnies!! Of course I had to go in!

I was greeted by a bevy of yummy pastries, colorful macaroons, and beautiful cakes! HMmmm!! How do you even choose what to get without
a) getting cavities
b) gaining 39405703 pounds
c) spending waaay too much money

I opted for a chocolate-dipped shortbread(?) cookie! Deeelicious! It was perfect...exactly the afternoon sugar rush I needed!

This bakeshop is really quaint-looking inside and I can see myself coming here in the future armed with a book and one of their pastries :)
Also, it's AWESOME that it's run by a father-daughter team! I wish my dad was cool enough to agree to open a bakeshop with me...
author: Kei H.

description:
I don't even know where to begin! I love Fillmore Bakeshop. I have been coming here for years. I absolutely love their pastries. Just to name a few that I often purchase (I haven't tried everything, but I slowly will. I have too many favorites that I keep purchasing!
