I will start venturing out): ham and cheese croissant, regular croissant, macaroons, quiches (all are absolutely delicious), cornmeal cookies, princess cake, cannolis. Oh and on Saturdays they have delicious focaccia!!

Also, the staff is amazing! Doug and Elena are the sweetest father-daughter duo. I love going into their bakery and being greeted by their warm, smiling faces. Maddie is an absolute sweetheart too!

My husband and I got married last month. When we started wedding planning we knew from the beginning that we were going to use Fillmore Bakeshop for our wedding cake. We worked with Elena on the wedding flavors and cake style. She was a delight! So easy going and flexible. The cake tasting was so much fun! She nailed it! The cake was absolutely beautiful and delicious. We also ordered macroons. Maddie did an amazing job on the macaroons! Everyone was raving about them!

If you haven't checked out this bakery you are missing out. Go, go now! This shop is a true gem and everyone that works here is amazing.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I have literally just died and got to macaroon heaven. 

$1.95 for each macaroon was a dollar well spent. I think my favorite of all the ones I bought was the pistachio. I purchased four: salted caramel, pistachio, coconut, and almond. I have never had macaroons before, but if heaven could be tasted... I swear to god I think this was it. 

The owners are really nice. They never hesitate to say hello when their customers walk in the door. And even Yuddi (I think that's how you spell it), is the nicest guy. He was very helpful with questions and always has a great big smile on his face ready to help you. He made my soy latte right on point. They only make hot coffees, no iced... which made me sad on a nice warm day but I don't think I was bothered by it too much since my eyes were more on the treats!

I think I'm a sucker for the macaroons in the blue look alike tiffany boxes with their hot soy lattes and decorative foam on the mug. I don't know how anyone can draw a leaf into my soy latte...it was too pretty to drink. I can't help it. Its pure heaven, pure decadence. This by far will be the reason I will constantly keep coming in... 

I have tried their croissants and they are fairly good as well, but its the macaroons hands down that win me. I know they are high in calories and full of sugar...but if I wanted to sin against my personal trainer for the weekend... this would be the winning idea. Thank you Fillmore bakery for making this tiny little cookie a melt in your mouth sweet treat!
author: Nathalie N.

description:
Our first "French touch" patisseries since we moved to the US a few months ago... and WOW! 
This shop's pastries are delicious. Tasted the apricot danish (mouth-watering) and chocolate croissant (so crispy)... And then just had some more their stuff is so good! Their apricot puff pastry tart is amazing as well, crisp and fresh.... Thank you for a warm welcome and delicious breakfast!
author: Connie R.

description:
Finally tried this place after having walked by for years.  Had a slice of Princess Cake and a rose macaroon.  I enjoyed the rose macaroon very much though I was disappointed with the Princess Cake.  I guess I was spoiled by the Swedish Bakery in Andersenville in Chicago during my years there.  This one was just a bit sweet and the cake lacked flavor.  It was also a little "coarse" - Princess cake has a thin layer of cream between the cake and marzipan covering.  This had thick layer and not enough custard in between the layers.

I'll try Schubert's Bakery next time.

Glad to know they have the cronuts here, someone offered me one in LA but I'm not compelled to try one.  I think idea of the combo is a bit much for me.  Sorry :-(
author: Favoloso M.

description: I love this place because of the cronuts, it's a must try. The downside is that they're very limited with them too since it's so popular. If you want to get a lot, the best thing to do is pre-order as there are limits to how many you can get if you just walk into the store.
author: Linda N.

description: this review is for the coffee and vibe. we came in for the coffee, which their sign announced was "better and cheaper than burger king's". We met the daughter. she was adorable and talked to us about tv and their coffee, which is rather good. like i'll always go there for coffee from now on if i'm in the neighborhood. it's true, coffee should not be $4. theirs was $1.75
author: Matt J.

description:
I didn't get that fresh bakery smell in my nose when I walked in.
It's a really cute and clean bakery with a very pretty display of their French Macarons (pronounced mac-a-roons.. we asked the worker HAHA)

My friends basically ordered one of everything they had and it came out to be about 14 bucks (at $1.95 each). I really wanted to try the salted caramel so I charged for that first. It wasn't as soft as I thought it would be though. It was thick and chewy (if you're into that, then this is the place for you!) I then had the passion fruit, which had a pretty purple coloring, but there was no flavor :(

I love my macarons soft and creamy, but this is more chewy and sweet! But I feel like I've had better at other places. The workers are very nice though, and you get to see them bake while you're ordering!
author: Linda K.

description:
I don't get the all the hype that macarons have been causing lately, but I have to say, Fillmore Bakeshop makes a GOOD macaron. I'm also not a macaron connoisseur by any means, but the green tea one and salted caramel one were so good that I was tempted to walk back from my car and buy some more. Mama seemed to enjoy her coconut macaroon as she was trailing 50 feet behind me and gobbling it down. YUMM.

The fillings for both were so divine and perfectly matched the lightly sweet cookie. AH I WANT MORE NOW. They had a whole bunch of other flavors as well, but I have been won over by these two. 

Will have to come back to try the other goodies!
author: Moraia W.

description:
Had my first S'mores bar from this place...So delicious!!!!I
It's a father & daughter operation, who doesn't love that?!
I've tried a bit of everything here and not one was bad.
author: Quinn S.

description:
You'd have to possess amazing willpower to pass by Fillmore Bakeshop without stopping in for a treat.  Believe me when I say they have EVERYTHING you could possibly be looking for at a bakery and every single item is gorgeous. 

It wasn't too busy while I was there, so I got to take my time weighing my choices and I ended up with two meringues.  One was a tiny chocolate meringe cookie sandwich, filled with a chocolate cream ($1) and the other was a white meringue strip topped with chocolate and slivered almonds ($1.50).  Yummy in my tummy.

I loved the guy manning the counter, decked out in his SF Giants shirt and hat.  He never stopped smiling...quite the opposite of many shopkeepers in this neighborhood.
author: Joanna L.

description:
I have been trying for the past hour to place an order for a cake through the phone. I've tried at least 10 different times, waiting more than a few minutes and each time I get a busy tone. I also tried on two different phones, just in case mine was being weird. Nope, still busy.

I'll be going to Mollie Stones, thanks.
author: Tevina T.

description: The cakes from here are simply the best. Fillmore Bakeshop made my wedding cake (strawberry soirée and ebony and ivory flavored). The cake was fantastic, both flavorful and beautiful.  They focus on flavor and make very elegant cakes, but if you're looking for extravagant sugar flowers this is not your place. If you're looking for a warm and wonderful place to try cake and a gorgeous and delicious cake for a special occasion, look no further!
author: Anne H.

description:
The macarons here are wonderful! My boyfriend and I stopped by for a short break after walking around the neighborhood. We had the rosewater and the green tea macarons.

The drinks here however are mediocre. I had a cappuccino that was adequate, and he ordered orange juice...which came out of a carton of kirkland orange juice.

So come for the baked goods, and not the drinks! And check out the consignment shops in the afterwards while you're at it :)
author: Patricia Q.

description:
I was shocked at the sales's plain all- about- business attitude. 

My two children love their Rose macaroon, we are here at least at least twice a week. but yesterday, I forget my wallet, but got some small change and a check book. I asked if I can pay with my one dollar and will came back the next day with $ 0.95 for one macaroon .  I don't want to waist a check for 95 cents. 

But the lady responded with a cold expression to me and my excited 4 years old, saying, " Sorry, I don't do that."

I wanted to walk out, but couldn't do that do my excited daughter. 

I wrote a check for $1. 95. 

Explained to my daughter, this is not a kid friendly shop, we are not coming back.
author: TRACEY C.

description:
Try a bit of everything including the Florentine's, French macaroons (i.e. pistachio, mint), chocolate chip pecan cookies, yuzu chocolate, and other sweet treats.  Of course, don't forget to try their Princess Cake and cheesecake.

Service is fast, friendly, and helpful.  The ambiance and decor is simple and clean with a window of goodies to choose from.  Parking can be tough on the streets, but this family bakeshop is worth a pit stop to satisfy your sweet tooth!
author: Jenny L.

description:
After a day at the Cherry Blossom Festival in Japantown, we were somewhat hungry and needed a caffeine boost. The street-food just didn't cut it. We spy "Bakeshop" and that meant sweet treats and most likely coffee. True enough, upon entering, we're greeted by a variety of baked goodies.

Wanting something more substantial, I order the hazelnut, apple coffee cake to go with my espresso. 

Verdict:

Hazelnut, apple coffee cake is good and not overly sweet as most coffee cakes tend to be. The top has a layer of hazelnuts and the somewhere near the base is a layer of apples. Kind of  like an applie pie in a cake. Good cake that goes excellent with, guess, coffee. Surprise!

Coffee is less impressive since they use Nespresso capsules for espresso. Decent espresso but not good enough to earn the 4th star overall. Pastries, cakes, etc. are 4 stars good though.
author: Norman S.

description: I was looking for a place in The City to try the Cronuts that were all the rage in New York and Google showed me The Bakeshop. After reading the reviews here (thank you for the long lines warning), my girlfriend & I are now hooked on those croissant/donut hybrids, but their other offerings are simply divine! The quiche lorraine is exquisite and the cheese danish is second to none! This place has become our standard by which all other bakeries are measured!
author: Dhar J.

description:
Cute French bakeshop!
The location is great - right on the corner but parking in this neighborhood can be tricky.
Pies, croissants, cookies...so many options!
I went straight for their bread pudding and coconut macarons.
author: Sara P.

description:
This is another family-owned dessert/bakery shop in SF which makes incredible sweet things. I went in to get some pastries for another office marketing program and I usually get their danish pastries [I especially like the cherry-filled ones]. It's in a convenient and prime location across from that behemoth known as Walgreens. The parking around here is a real b*tch most times, but which area of SF isn't? [Probably an area I wouldn't want to venture into]. 

Anyway:
- support your local businesses, 
- buy their pastries, and 
- run those extra miles!
author: Derek N.

description: LOVE this place! Visited during Fillmore Jazz Festival weekend and they are the most friendly people ever! When you walk in, everything just looks and smells so delicious! Lattes a must! Everything is very reasonably priced! Come here anytime youre in the area, you wont be disappointed!
author: Anita S.

description:
I have a bucket list of bakeries on my quest to sample San Francisco's best of my all time favorite gluten free treat: the french macaroon. Fillmore Bakeshop has been a must try on my agenda of sampling every macaroon in the city.

Family owned and operated, Fillmore Bakeshop has a cute little store front on Fillmore's lively shopping street. Service is attentive and friendly - I spent a good 15 minutes chatting with the owners on French macaroons and what makes their selection special. I found out they are one of the only Bay area bakeries that makes all of their french macaroons by hand (most other bakeries now mass-produce this confection). Made from the finest ingredients and piped with fresh buttercream filling,  Fillmore Bakeshop's treats are larger than most. Eating one of their cookies will take you more than a few bites. They offer a wide selection of flavors in all sorts of fun colors. I chose to try the classic Almond macaroon with fresh almond buttercream. The texture was unlike any other macaroons I have sampled - different and delicious. While I didnt find the flavor to be as intense as other macaroons, the fresh almond buttercream filling really made the cookie standout. I cant wait to go back to try their bright green pistachio macaroon and fluffy meringue - those treats look simply divine!

To try a macaroon thats homemade and heavenly, get your butt over to Fillmore street. THANKS Fillmore bakery for a delicious treat!
author: Caroline J.

description: Quite possibly the best macaron I've had in my life. Light and fluffy with a subtly sweet filling. Tried a slice of the salted carmel cake as well. Divine. There are 2 small tables inside - so not the best for large groups. Looks like they have coffee and espresso, just didn't try any so can't report on that. Missed the cronuts which come out at 9am so will have to come back!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Was in SF this past weekend for a short visit, and we decided to stop in after walking up and down Fillmore. Caught a whiff of the glutenous goodness before even walking inside, but had no idea what an experience awaited me.

At first I couldn't decide which pastry to try, but then I caught a glimpse of the macarons, and it was love at first sight. I sampled the lemon, blood orange, and salted caramel, and let me tell you, their macarons are just as good as any I had in Paris. Oh, yeah, and the Samoa (the Girl Scout cookie, not the island nation) brittle was amazing too.

The bakery is family owned, and everyone in there is really nice. So nice, in fact, that this is the first time I've felt compelled to write a review on Yelp.

Next time we come to town, we're bringing you a dozen Diddy Riese cookies in exchange for some macarons!
author: Andrew A.

description:
My review of this bakeshop is not about its baked goods, but about the employees working there yesterday morning around 10 am.  They are all b*****s and snooty, except for one!!!  I went there for their famous cronuts, only to find out that they don't make them on Tuesdays.  When I informed the girl who "helped" me (with an attitude) that it doesn't even say it on their website, she just brushed me off and turned her back.  SOOOO RUDE!!!.  Then another employee approached me, I told her how disappointing it was because I came all the way from the other side of the Bay Bridge; and I made a suggestion to include this information on their website.  She was genuinely sympathetic.  While talking to her I notice these 3 "girls" (the other employees, including the first one I talked to) talking to each other while giving me a nasty look, and saying "what's her problem/what does she want".  Then one of them approached me and rudely took over.  She has so much attitude, and she's a liar too!  She told me that information about not having cronuts on Tuesdays is stated on their Facebook page.  1: not every single person has a Facebook account; 2: I checked both their website & Facebook page before I went there!!!  She suggested to get their business card and call first before I go there next time.  Woman, who told you I will go there again, after a very unpleasant experience with you and the rest of your pack of snoots???  Your bakeshop is not the only one around.  
Word got to me that the owners are the same!!!  What a shame!  You are in a diverse city!
author: Jay C.

description:
Whoever thought to highlight their colorful assortment of macaroons behind the huge glass counter is a genius.  It was really what drew both me and my boyfriend in, and the owner was very polite and friendly, and had introduced all of his bakers to us by first name. 

There was something off about the texture of the meringue on a few of the macaroons I had selected a variety of..
2 Lemon, tasty but I would prefer it to be more zesty than the tartness I tasted.
1 Pistachio, very savory.
1 Blood Orange, tasty
1 Green tea, COMPLETELY INTOXICATING
1 Almond, I think this was the one I had a problem with -something about the texture was off, like it was too airly and brittle.  But the filling itself was actually good, I am a big fan of almond flavors so maybe I had really had subconsciously set higher standards for this little macaroon apart from the rest.  But this definitely doesn't deter me from trying another one next time because the other ones were so good.

We also had a stone fruit tart that was good, I am not really a fan of them. But then again, it wasn't me that ordered it, I just merely had a bite of his.. he couldn't stop raving about it.

I can't wait to come back.
author: Ty T.

description: Really great local bakery, on Fillmore Street.  I went there today and got a slice of cherry pie!!! I love that I can have the option to just get one fresh slice of pie! Also they have these really cool stuffed bagel things, but you have to get there early for those.
author: Moran G.

description: Had my first cronut here. Wow it was great, maybe its because it super fresh and still warm
author: David K.

description: Everything they have here is good, especially the pies.  I also really like their merengues when they have them.  For savory, their focaccias are delicious.  To me, it's one of the only food spots on this entire stretch of Fillmore that has any kind of integrity or soul.
author: Jon N.

description:
Citizens of shi-shi foodie SF, wtf is up with all of this macaron madness at Fillmore Bakeshop?  If you really want a cookie pick-me-up in the middle of the afternoon, I only have two words for you: Hazelnut Sable.  It may not look as frou-frou as those colorful macarons, but this cookie is seriously one of the best combination of flavors and textures I've ever tasted (and I've been to Paris, bitches).  It's nutty, crispy, crumbly, sweet, soft (but not too soft, more like firm), and has that perfect amount of smooth dark chocolate at the very end.  Oh, and they serve glasses of milk too. :-)

As for other items in this lovely bakeshop, I had a friend in from NYC visit recently who hadn't had a real marzipan Princess Cake since he was a child, and the only bakery in NYC that did it closed when he was 12.  Upon tasting Fillmore Bakeshop's *real* marzipan Princess Cake, he proclaimed it just as good if not better than the cake of his childhood.  And how could he not? It's the perfect combo of tasty marzipan, light cake, whipped cream, and raspberry jam.   Perfect for special occasions or when your friend from NYC is getting on your nerves and you eat a slice before giving him the rest of the cake.

Lastly, Fillmore Bakeshop may not be as precious or avante-garde as Citizen Cake or Miette, but quite honestly SF has enough of those places anyway.  What Elena and her staff do best is straightforward, honest, delicious pastries and cakes that don't need lace doilies to be exceptional. The proof is in the pudding, as people say (oh, and do try the bread pudding!).
author: Michelle N.

description: I was caught in a desperate dash to procure a pie for Thanksgiving dinner the day of. Fortunately, Fillmore Bakeshop's doors were open at a time when most of the bakeries were already closed on the holiday, and I was able to pick up a fresh pecan pie that proved to be perfectly balanced in flavor and texture. I will undoubtedly be back to try more of their baked goods.
author: Jay D.

description:
We visit the bakery every Saturday and Sunday for breakfast. 

The best pastries in town. 
Not overwhelmingly rich. Light enough for our enjoyment and a 10 miles run soon after.

We love the bread pudding, croissants, and all goodies Doug, Elena and the team bake. 
Special mention  goes to the cookies, macaronis, princess and chocolate cakes. 

When we are in the mood for something savory, we take home Doug's focaccia. Delicious.

Finally, everybody is very friendly. The best way to start the weekend days.
author: Giovanni T.

description:
$1500 is affordable for a beautiful wedding cake, but I will not buy for bad customer services. 

I walked by the shop today, a beautiful wedding cake caught my attention.  So I went in to shop asking for its price.  A innocent young looking gentleman came forward knowing that I may have questions or need services.  I asked how much it is for that 4 lay cake.  He first answered it is a wedding cake.  In side of my head thinking..."okay...I think I need that is a wedding cake"...Then I asked how much it is for a wedding cake that size?  He had no certain answers, which is understandable.  Maybe designs differentiate the price.  Anyhow, a young white blond lady works in the shop standing in the back and staring at me the whole time like "What do you want to know?".  Finally she opened her lovely mouth and stated, "A cake like that costs at least $1000.  and you need to ask the cake maker for prices if you want to..."

Okay, the cake maker came forward answered my questions...I commented her it is a beautiful cake and left the shop pretended pleasant. 

I hope the shop owner reads this review and works  on improving their customer services.
author: Bei K.

description:
What exactly should be the make up of a great butter croissant?  Does it need to flake to bits like a rusty fence when you breathe on it?  Or, like the city of San Francisco, should it survive a bit of a shake, with its exterior mostly intact and its interior as wonderful as ever?   I think the latter.  Give me strength with beauty every time.

Fillmore Bakeshop's croissant was excellent but didn't fall apart on me.  And that's what I need, a strong partner in hunger alleviation, accepting of its fate and joyful in its desire to complete its mission, not a shrinking violet, fearful of my glance, going all to pieces on my shirt with the knowledge of what's to come.

Jeez that was a good croissant...
author: Joe N.

description:
My boyfriend and I were off discovering the beautiful city of SF and we discovered this little gem thanks to Yelp!

It's a pretty small and unassuming store front when you pass by.  We came to try some of their macaroons that came highly recommended.  We ordered an assortment of about 12 varying in chocolate, coconut, some berry flavor I can't recall, but was SO good.  The lady behind the counter was really attentive and gave us great recommendations.  I would definitely make another trip to the city to devour more of their macaroons!
author: Meryl P.

description: The Almond croissant was quite good, although not the best I've had in the city (shout out to Thorough Bread!). I did like it though, and the almond paste wasn't sickeningly sweet. And of course we had to try a cronut (fried croissant!!) which was obviously yummy, but not something I want to eat every day!!
author: Ana Y.

description: Was in San Fran in May on vacation and had heard this bakery makes cronuts so we stopped for a visit. It was a little hard to find and when we got there found out they only offer them a few days a week. So we returned another day and have to say they were worth the effort. They were soo delicious. Now I understand what all the hype is about. The bakery itself is really cute. Nice and clean and offers a nice variety of baked goods. Will go back to this place next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Susan B.

description:
Sadly,  it has been quite a while since I ventured onto Fillmore Street for food and shopping.  I had no idea that Delanghe Patiserrie had closed shop!   Today during my wanderings I noticed the very cute Fillmore Bakeshop in its place.  

I actually was wanting lunch, but couldn't resist the colorfulness of the shop and had to drop in.  

I'm a huge cupcake-a-holic, who has recently acquired a fancy for LES MACARONS and chocolate truffles (thanks to my dear friend, Fred); therefore, it may not be so surprising that I was drawn IMMEDIATELY to the clear glass case filled with macarons, truffles and slices of cake. I peered like a CHILD, with wide eyes on Christmas morning, at the baked goods in front of me.

In the end, I settled for what sounded and looked the most delicious to me:  the salted caramel chocolate mousse cake.  I also ordered a cup of black coffee (sans room for cream) and a morning bun to carry home for later.  

I was literally SALIVATING with excitement to try the cake and I was NOT disappointed!    The salted caramel chocolate mousse cake was melt in my mouth delicious decadence!  The mousse was airy and light and not overly sweet.  The icing on the cake was firm and perfectly juxtaposed the texture of the mousse in my opinion. Plus the salt on the icing added depth and perfect contrast to the chocolate sweetness and balance to the caramel, which is present in subtle hints within the icing. Most importantly, the cake is moist and the slice is exactly the RIGHT size for a tasting, but not too much that there are leftovers ;-).

PS - the coffee is WONDERFUL. Not too strong and perfect sans cream for those coffee drinkers who want to shave off unnecessary calories from cream/milk. Also, dark, it complements the sugar present in the dessert for perfect balance!

For a slice of the cake, a regular sized cup of coffee, & a morning bun, I spent around $11.  I also purchased some freshly made coconut macaroons at $1/piece. 

I just ate the morning bun, which was covered with granulated sugar on the outside with a hint of cinnamon layered on the inside, which was not overpowering heavy and would have paired greatly with a cup of coffee.  

While I was there, several women walked in raving about their coconut macaroon, so I had to purchase some.  I tried the coconut macaroon, which was crispy on the outside and flakey, sweet coconut on the inside. For me, this dessert was a little too sweet for my liking.

I'm very happy to have found this cute, family owned bake-shop near my apartment.  I'll be back with friends again.
author: Hiromi N.

description: was here with a good friend as we were walking around the neighborhood. we shared a piece of pumpkin pie and got a tea and a soy latte. they were all great, especially the coffee. they have so many cute and tasty treats that it was hard for us to just pick one. the cookies and cakes are made with such attention to detail that it shows. highly recommend stopping here to experience some of their sweets and maybe take some home to share as well.
author: Ms B.

description: Cute place! The desserts are amazing. We got the hazelnut cake and it was absolutely delicious. So rich and smooth and soft at the same time. The bear claw is very good as well and goes well with a coffee. Everything here is delicious and must get! Can't wait to come back for some more cake. Only downside was one of staff members was not well informed about the cakes and pastries.
author: Shireen J.

description:
Great local bakery.  Excellent bread pudding; made daily.  Very entertaining and lively pastry chef.

I have fondness for bread pudding and Fillmore Bakeshop has dethroned my previous favorite, Tartine, in terms of quality and taste.  Fillmore Bakeshop's recipe accents the flavor of the bread and the sweetness of the fruit, while Tartine's recipe focuses too much on egg and heavy cream.  Also, it is nice to experience prompt and friendly customer service.

The pastry chef. Elena, is Swiss trained and she has the fire of a jilted Southern debutante.  She is absolutely hysterical; a possible contender for New York-level of repartee.
author: Brandon R.

description:
This is our favorite bakery in San Francisco! My husband and I have a weekly ritual of going every Friday morning, and look forward to it all week. My favorites are the hazelnut raisin bread or the chocolate croissants, and my husband likes their morning bun & their fruit pastries.

It's so refreshing to find a place with owners that care to hand make all of their goods after so many mass market chain bakeries (you know who I'm talking to, bakery on Pine & Fillmore street).

AND... we just had the passion fruit mango mousse cake which was absolutely to die for. I'm a chocolate person, and my husband's a fruit person, and it was the perfect marriage (no pun intended) of both. 

Overall, we couldn't recommend this place more highly.
author: Beth G.

description: I went on a Friday morning at 8am and tried their blueberry bread pudding - exceptional! At around 8:52 they started serving the cronuts and a few people were in line. By 9:05a there was a busy line out the door. On a Friday! Impressive. Limit is 6 per person. The sugared cronut was definitely good and worth trying it for the novelty but the bread pudding is really what i would go back for. Very friendly staff, the father/daughter establishment is top notch.
author: Trisha H.

description:
This review is for their macaroons only!  Which are amazing-the flavors the texture-all of it.  I especially loved this caramel one and the coffee one and this pistachio one and this blood orange one and ...well, you get the idea.  I suggest bringing a ton of them for dessert to a party so that you have an excuse to sample a bunch of them in one sitting.

Thinking about serving macaroons instead of cake for my wedding. Hope that goes over well!
author: Gaia M.

description:
OMG, so much buttery goodness.  This place is so good I try NOT to go in to protect my pie hole from all the pie.  

Also, great marks for being nice.  And liking the puppies.
author: Katrina S.

description:
Have I mentioned I LOVE macarons?  Even after binging on various desserts at Citizen Cake, I couldn't help but stop in after seeing macarons from the outside.  I took a Passion Fruit, Almond, and Green Tea.  The Almond is not as good as Paulette's because the flavor is not as strong.  The Passion Fruit though is pretty intense yet not too sweet.

I must come back and try their other flavors and pastries.  To be continued...
author: Linh V.

description:
Just an absolutely incredible place. I came in here for the first time and my eyes nearly bugged out of my head when I saw the macaron case. A WHOLE CASE for macarons!!! There must have been at least ten flavors: chocolate, pistachio, vanilla, cranberry, black licorice, honey lavender, rose, raspberry, lemon, blood orange, coconut, ... I can't remember them all but it was heaven just looking at them.
Elena helped me out and she was extremely friendly and helpful, making great recommendations on which favors I should try. When she saw that I was into the rose macarons, she offered me one of the lavenders that had a crack in it, since it wouldn't be right to sell it anyways. Score! I had such a great experience here, the macarons are mind-blowing, and I will certainly be back!
author: Rachel A.

description:
Eveything here is amazing!  The wonderful owners made our wedding cake and it was the most beautiful, delicious cake I could have imagined!

Everyone at the wedding said it was "out of this world"!

I can't say enough about this amazing place!
author: Kristin C.

description: Came here to try the cronuts but they were sold out already :( So I tried their macarons. I tried their blackberry, lemon and pistachio flavors. It was pretty good, not too sweet and it was definitely fresh. The only kinda too sweet one was the lemon one but it wasn't over bearing. 4 stars for the macarons but 3 star for the place in general since I didn't try their cronuts yet! D;
author: Ruhjeenuh Z.

description:
I love Fillmore Bakeshop, and I love Elena! My husband and I asked Fillmore Bakeshop to do our wedding cake and Elena was so, so, sweet and helpful.  She was super accommodating and we got exactly what we wanted.  She was so cute; she said when we chose her to make our cake, she felt like she won a prize!

Not only was Elena super helpful with the cake, but she gave us recommendations about all sorts of things like places to get good deals on favor wrapping, etc.  Now that's what I call customer service!

We now visit the bakeshop whenever we're in the area, and have found all the normal bakeshop fare to be tasty and delicious. Items on our personal can't miss list include the bread pudding (different and yummy every time!), princess cake, salted caramel cake, and the marzipan (if you like marzipan, you will LOVE theirs).  They make everything fresh here and you can tell.

Customer service has always been pleasant and swift whenever we've been in and we've frequented the place fairly often, so I'm not sure why there was a one-star review about service.

All in all, just a great overall spot to grab something to satisfy your sweet tooth.
author: Kristina D.

description:
A little bakery located on Fillmore Street.  The shop itself is clean and neat.  The staffs were friendly, welcome and sweet.  

I got a Raspberry and a Peanut Butter Macarons.  It was about $1.95 each.  Both of the macarons were very good.  Very good flavor, rich, chewy but not too sweet.  

I would definitely go back there to try other flavors of macarons!
author: Liza T.

description:
Okay, so this place is the bomb of all bombs and I don't mean in a scary wipe out the earth sort of way, unless of course you were going to start by killing my taste buds with pure flavorful bliss. Yup I could not be more in love.

The Dirt: Since this place opened, my partner and I have become loyal Sunday brunchers. Why? Because it is sooooooo tasty. The pastries are beautiful to look at, even more delicious to taste, and will not fill you up because there are no extra fillers. This is the real thing. One of my favs being veggie is the Mushroom Spinach Quiche, but you have to go early because this puppy flies out the door. The quiche is light and leaves me wanting more. I take this as a good sign. Wanting is always better than moving on... in anything.

What Sealed the Deal: Elena & Uri(yup probably spelled that incorrectly) are always amazing and great conversationalists and although that woud be enough on top of all the amazing pastries, there was one thing that pushed us over to lifers....the Chocolate Hazelnut Cake.... Oh it's far beyond amazing and absolutely one of the most beautiful cakes I have ever seen. This cake is a must try at least once. We took it to my partner's birthday and it was a huge hit. Probably should not be eating it almost a week later, but it was too good to let go of...

So, if you have not tried this place out, it is well worth it. Go early or you may miss out on some gems. Fillmore Bakeshop is locally owned and family run ( dad and daughter). 

Sunday is almost here and we cannot wait!
author: Trane W.

description: Someone brought a bunch of pastries from Fillmore Bakeshop and now I want to actually GO to the store to try them! Super savory and a fine example of how good pastries should be. I tried an assortment of pastries but the overall feeling was "now I need to make a trip out there".
author: Diana Y.

description:
...timid, because this is my first review...but!
I just had to write, only 5 minutes after my exit from this store with 3 goodies in my hands: an orange/almond/butter cookie, one yellow caked/chocolate frosting/"butterfinger-like" topping cupcake, and an orange cupcake with all kinds of fancy orange zest/icing/cake/etc.

First of all, the service was GREAT. The nice cashier was helping another woman with some macaroons but she still relayed a very friendly, "Hello! Welcome!" It's always being nice acknowledged by an establishment, even when they are busy.

Now the goodies:
1. Orange/almond/butter cookie: YUM YUM YUM! I read some other reviews saying they couldn't taste the butter in their treats, but not so with this scrumptious cookie. I probably devoured it in under 30 seconds.

2. Yellow cake/chocolate frosting/"butterfinger-like" topping cupcake: The fiance inhaled it. He reluctantly asked if I wanted a bite, so I took a small taste. Any bigger than a small taste and I think he would have cried. I'm not really a big fan of peanuts so I can't give a fair review, but the chocolate frosting was very smooth and not too sweet...it almost tasted like whipped pudding. YUM.

3. Fancy orange everything cupcake: I'm saving this for after dinner, but I am almost certain I will consume this in under 30 seconds, again.

Thank you nice cashier and really cool pastry chef! Everything from the friendly and prompt service and the delicious pastries made my Saturday evening quite wonderful. See you again soon!!!

P.S.
I LOVE your napkins!! They're not only very pretty but enormous. It really helps getting all the crumblies and frosting off of my face.
author: Jung Ah R.

description:
Are you kidding me, people who gave anything lower than a 5? This place is it for sweet tooths everywhere. A sucker for anything dessert-like, this place drew me in like flies to honey or, more accurately, a sweet tooth to a bakeshop. 

Sadly, a gluten-free lifestyle (not by choice) has vastly limited the options for fulfilling my sugar cravings. But walk into Fillmore Bakeshop and I'm greeted by a rainbow of beautiful, perfectly puffed, mouth-watering, eye-satisfying, taste bud-teasing, GLUTEN-FREE macarons! They seem to come out with a new flavor every month and NEVER disappoint. 

Or, for the non-restricted, just close your eyes and point to the pastry case. I guarantee you'll like whatever lands in your mouth. What else? They make their own chocolates, it's run by a super-friendly, super-awesome (hi, Elena!) father-daughter team (yeah family businesses!) and they carry a nice coffee from a small roaster from my home state of PA. 

I can't say enough about this place. Please, do yourself a favor and check it out immediately.
author: Rachael M.

description:
The staff are all wonderful and they had this thin, buttery cookie that was just a perfect afternoon pick me up.
Princess cake was a hit with my friends too.
author: Yasmin M.

description:
I wanted to like this place. I really did. The people were nice but I wasn't a fan. I bought the chocolate, green tea, hazelnut, and caramel macarons. The macrons were huge but I didn't like them.

The cookie: 
The crust should be smooth and so thin, it's like a useless shell of protection for the lightly chewy yet soft cookie layer beneath it. What I got was a hard shell and a very chewy cookie. It can look undercooked but this was way too much.

The filling:
It should be smooth, light, firm-ish (like ganache), and not sticky. 
But what I got was smooth, too firm, a bit heavy, and sticky. The green tea filling was actually okay but I didn't like the others.


You know biting into a macaron is like a process, right? You experience every single texture and taste... I met hard surface that shattered when I expected an easy bite and my face went from ^__^ to o_O. Then I met the filling in the middle and my face drop from o_O to =(. I was truly disappointed. 

This may be good to some but I prefer the macarons at La Boulange in downtown.
author: Shirlene K.

description: These guys are incredible!  We come to SF several times a year and always stay in Japantown around the corner.  We are waiting at the door for pastries before they open every day!  AMAZING pastries!  Keep up the good work!
author: Clinton L.

description: A dangerous place to live a few feet from! The most amazing croissants - try a warmed ham and cheese. Authentic pretzels (owner is a Swiss baker). Macaroons that make great gifts. And pies to die for! All their ingredients are of the highest quality, you can watch the pastry chefs weaving their magic and the prices are reasonable.
author: Maria S.

description: Best cronuts in town hands down. Stop by early and get them while the are still hot (they don't last long anyway). Tried a few other treats and loved them all but I wished they had the Kouing Aman.
author: Ike W.

description: This review is for lack of service. I was here a few months ago and enjoyed a great cup of coffee and 2 macaroons. .all was terrific.  Just found out they also make cronuts.so stopped in. One couple ahead of us  and we have no problem waiting..we ultimately left because we were never acknowledged. .another client came in after us and was immediately acknowledged by the other employee who appeared to be the baker. He also never made an attempt to acknowledge us. A simple smile and a "we'll be right with you" was all we needed.  Stuff looks fabulous but we probably will not be back.
author: Maggie M.

description:
I like macarons like some people like cupcakes - I hunt them down and have to try them from everywhere.  I have been lucky enough to try the Sprüngli "Luxemburgerli" macarons in Zurich, using a 175 year old recipe, I basically thought there was no topping them and that I'd be forever ruined on macarons. I mean, why bother after that - they're magnificent and perfect.

So, having tried several in the city that were nothing to speak of, I stumbled into the Fillmore Bakeshop seeking some other kind of sweet treat and decided, "Well, I'll give San Francisco macarons one more chance."  To the other reviewers who think they're too crispy on the outside and then chewy on the inside, they're SUPPOSED to be like that.  These are not whoopie pies.  They're made with eggs, not cake. 

Honestly, these macarons gave Sprüngli a run for their money.  When I mentioned my experience in Switzerland to the young woman helping me, she exclaimed, "That's near where I did my internship! In Switzerland!!"  No surprise here.  Other than the size and the slightly more American names for flavors (Salted Caramel aka Fleur de Sel), they were the same level of quality and taste. I will definitely be going back. 

If only they had.... delivery.... dun dun DUNNNNNNN!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
HOLY SMOKES!!! AMAZING macarons!!!!!!

Here on a Friday around noon, I walk in and the place smells of the most amazing butter smell ever.

The trays of macarons looked amazing!  I hear the gentleman behind the counter tell the customer in front of me that the macarons are differnt shapes b/c he makes them by hand and sometimes his eyes aren't perfect (how cute is that!?)

Overall....I'm usually not a fan of buttercream filling AT ALL, but these have changed my mind completely!
The filling is not like thick butter frosting (which is what I've experienced in the past), it was light, and melt in your mouth, doesn't coat you mouth in butter at all.  All the flavors were refreshing, tasted REAL, and not overly sweet.
The shells were perfect as well....light and airy with a little chew to them.

and ummmm...chocolate peanut butter macaron!?!?!  why has no one done this before?!?

Almond....fantastic
Vanilla....I would not put the sugar on top...other than that, perfect
Passion Fruit....HELLO JUICY!! :)
Rose....amazing, not too perfumy like some others
Salted Caramel.....light and not overpowering, again fantastic
Strawberry...also very juicy (how do you get that juicy flavor !?!)
Hazelnut....good, but the others were just sooooo much better.
Blood Orange....awesome!


I have a request Fillmore Bakeshop.....Earl Grey Please!

P.S.  I LOVE the little cute handle box I took my macarons home in!
I may have to start writing little love notes
author: Q L.

description: Best Almond Croissants in San Francisco.  Go early to get them because they sell out.  Everything else is good as well.
author: Aban E.

description:
It's not the mistake; it's the effort to make it better.
Elena and her staff are a class act. I'll be seeing about the fantastic cronuts (and more) at Fillmore Bakeshop very soon.
author: Tonya M.

description: My daughter brings me macarons from this bakery and they are some of the best macarons I have ever had.I have tasted macaroons from laduree and other famous ones in Paris and  London and these ones are better. Their hazelnut one is fantastic and caramel one and passion fruit. In fact they are all good.
author: Anna S.

description: I went there to check out their famous bread pudding and cronuts. Doesn't seem to have much for sales there. The bread pudding looks really sweat with a lot of jams. so i ended up not buying anything and left.
author: Ashley C.

description: Fine delicate pastries. A treat to look at and to gobble up.
author: Jeneal J.

description: They might have the best pie in San Francisco. I had a slice of the apple pie and jt did not disappoint. It was the best crust I've ever had. Flaky, moist, and crisp!!  Next time I'm in the neighborhood I'll try a different favor of their pie. The search for the best slice of pie continues.
author: Dominic P.

description: By far the best bakery we've been to in the city. We haven't tried anything that we did not absolutely love. In fact, we had to fight for some of their pastries with other patrons, it's so good. Our favorites are: pies (full of fruit and delicious), bread pudding (just like I wish I could make them - with custard and fruit), princess cake (closest cake this side of the Atlantic that resembles an Astro-Hungarian dessert). They do bake their sweets throughout the day, so you need to come early for cronuts, and later for the pies and bread pudding. Staff is friendly and efficient.  Only drawback I can think of: There are two tiny tables for those that want to sit and enjoy the desserts on site. We usually do take-out, so it's not a problem.
author: Lajos M.

description:
I just had the best macaroon of my life!  It was the coconut macaroon if you're interested.  I'm saving the blackberry and the chocolate for the rest of my family when they get home later - it will be hard...
So needless to say, I love the sweets here.  This was my third visit...and I also think the folks that work here / own it are really, really nice.  Go visit!  Delicious and beautiful sweets!
author: Tracey E.

description:
The croissants here are TDF, and their other pastries aren't bad either. I've even tried the pies and cookies, and those are delish as well.
Note if you want a whole pie you have to order ahead.
I took one star off for the high prices, but what can you expect from french pastries?
author: Nancy O.

description:
Walking down the street after checking out Japaneses bath house, my fat kid was screaming at me.  There it was Fillmore Bakeshop with all the goodies staring at me.  My heart was set on quiche and sure enough my wish came true!  The gentleman behind the counter was very nice and helpful.  

While I was enjoying my quiche a lovely french couple tells me that the biscotti is like home.  So of course I had to take some home to Phoenix with me.  And boy I'm glad I did!  Next time I'm going to bring a friend and have the bread pudding.
author: sophia c.

description:
WOW!  Happened to walk in on their Wednesday opening this week, chatted with both the daughter (Elena) and her dad, who own/run this place.  Tried:
Chocolate Ganache Cookie (which has some German sounding name I can't recall):  two light buttery chocolate cookies with a smoosh of chocolate ganache in the center, not too sweet, really lovely.  Oatmeal Raisin Cookie:  excellent texture, perfect amount of ingredients, appropriately chewy.  And finally, the Chocolate Croissant Bread Pudding:  simply amazing, the best I have had anywhere outside of my mother in law's (who made the most amazing French pastries).  

As we have a dinner party coming up this weekend, and time/energy to bake is short these days with the new baby in the house, we (the hubby, who also highly approved the bread pudding, which is speaking volumes) decided that we would bring Fillmore Bakeshop's Choco Croissant Pudding.  So I walk in this afternoon, day three, to see about it.  None in the case, and Elena mentioned that they kept running out of croissants.  Then ensued funny interchange in which I think I may have offended them to their core... sorry!
  
Me:  "Oh do you make your own croissants here?"
Elena [over her shoulder to her Dad]:  "Hey Dad, do we make our own croissants here?"
Elena's Dad:  [rolling his eyes and jokingly waving me out of the shop] "Ahhh, get outta here!"  
Me:  [stumbling realizing I'd done some offending and trying to make up for it] "OOh.  So how early do I have to get here to taste these lovely croissants?"  
Elena or Elena's Dad:  "We open at 7!"

Next, Elena offered to bake me the Choco Croissant Pudding herself if I brought in a casserole dish for her to bake it in.  Wow, talk about a super sweet surprise!  Now that is above and beyond.  Which of course, as she herself suggested, leaves me the option of passing it off as my own (but we shall see where my moral compass goes on that one...)  The hugest part was that she even offered to teach me how to make it!!  Now that is a HUGELY exciting prospect for me.  

Then I tried a square of a Coconut Apricot Bar that she recommended (hearty texture, light, not too sweet, not too overly coconut, a delightfully thin bar that tasted kind of healthy even) as well as a Raspberry Custard Danish (soft yummy pastry, not dried out even at the end of the day, good balance of 4 raspberries sitting atop custard cheese, yum).  

Love the fact that it's a father/daughter pair working there.  Interior has been updated from the previous Patisserie Delanghe.  Modernized, really feels clean, and some serious baking going on here.  (I think they start at some ungodly hour like 3 or 4 am...  How can you not respect that.)  I hear that more tables/chairs have been purchased and are waiting to be picked up.    

Soooo... now I just have to make it to the Bakeshop in the morning some time to taste these delicious croissants.  And find a sitter to watch the baby so that I can learn Elena's delicious recipe for Choco Croissant Pudding!!!  So glad they are in the hood.
author: Isabel M.

description: Their macaroons here are delicious! It was actually my first time trying them EVER when I came here. I wanted to try every flavor (since I was getting pretty excited) but settled on about five since they're pretty pricey (just under $2). But not bad considering the macaroons at La Boulange are $2 each and way smaller. And luckily I actually prefer them here (even though LB's macaroons come in an adorable box). The macaroons are just the right amount of crispy on the outside yet aren't difficult to eat. I especially love their raspberry and green tea macaroons!
author: Jenny C.

description: This bakery is hands down one of the best I've been to.  Of all the macaroons Ive had, this bakery's macaroons were the best.  the salted caramel one was worth every single penny and the service was great!
author: Sam L.

description:
I've passed by this place so many times. I stopped here on a Monday and it was closed. A friend surprised me with 6 beautifully colored macarons in a cute blue box. I was excited and then I bit into one. The cookie crumbled and pieces fell on my clothes and floor. Bummer! I was anticipating a mouthwatering juicy bite and it turned out to be air and more cookie than filling. 

I normally like lavender but like my hubby said he said it tasted like soap. It's true the lavendar was overpowering. He did say he liked the mocha flavored macaron. I would go somewhere else for macarons but the cakes and other treats looked good. I considered getting a mango mousse cake from here because it was so nicely decorated.
author: Candace F.

description:
BEST. MACARONS. IN. SAN. FRANCISCO. 

NO LIE.

I live right where Alamo Square "historic" district meets Hayes Valley, and I have gone to La Boulange, Miette, Paulette, and a few other places that (discretely) sell these little sandwiched gems of cookies. I've even had them at certain 5 star hotels (while gigging) right around, oh, California and Mason, prepared by expert caterers and patisseurs. And they don't measure up!

I went in after Sunday Brunch upon seeing some pastries in case displays and was delighted to find rows and rows of macarons. I also found some creme puffs dipped in hard caramel (i'm a caramel fan!) and some other very pretty pastry items. The shop didn't even have a sign or fancy decor, but something sucked me in.

I decided, skeptical, to taste a macaron before paying for it. While picking out some other items, including the aforementioned creme puff, and another finger-sized eclair, I decided thereafter that to do that would be tasteless, so I bought just two little ones, and took a bite while my card was being run through the register. My first words were "OMG" right into the eyes of our gracious patisseur herself, and I left the store a happy patron, thinking of when it would be that I'll return.

Within two seconds I was back for another half-a-dozen macarons. I couldn't resist their smooth and crunchy almond shell with almost a fudgy, but still light, texture of the cookie paired with a most silky smidgeon of their delightful buttercream, not to mention the flavors really packed a punch. The creme puffs were delicious too. Everything is priced competitively, and served with a hint of charm, courtesy of the master bakere-ess at work here.

I would definitely recommend a trip in for a delectable, quick, on-the-go snack that will send you off into Paris for a moment. You won't be disappointed.
author: Y K.

description: This place is amazing, I recently stepped in to buy a few macaroons for a friend and was so delighted by the assortment of flavors, that I consumed a couple on my way out the door.  Please try the peanut butter and jelly, peanut butter filling and the outer crust is hiding the jelly in it, I think....either way, amazing!  Must try...
author: Casie M.

description:
This is how bad their salted caramel macaron was. 

I took a bite, spit it out, downloaded Yelp, and started drafting this review all within the same block.

I do not recommend their salted caramel macaron. The man who was behind the counter wasn't very friendly or helpful. The store gets an extra star because the female baker was hella nice and smiled and said hi from afar.
author: Matt Y.

description:
While heading off to SPQR on the next block we found a parking right outside this shop. That's my brag. My beat is that it was only for half an hour so we had to move on.

But not before checking out this shop. It's an active bakery with a great selection of items from maccaroons to eclairs.

It has a few tables to munch your wares there, but also does takeaways.

 But what caught my attention was a mille feuilles. Now she mentioned it by a different name, but what it is, is a slice of cake comprised of layers of flaky pastry, with a custard centre, topped with more flaky pastry and glazed icing. Outside of Europe, this is the best (only?) one I've seen of any quality. Try it out.
author: Pantera W.

description: Love, love, love the Fillmore bakeshop for their bread pudding. I think they have it available everyday with a different fruit filling. I've had the blueberry, and raspberry. I come in exclusively for the bread pudding. The portion size is perfect for a one person indulgence. Sometimes I just want to order the whole thing vs just the slice. I dream about this bread pudding. I have also tried their morning buns, holiday themed kids cookies, chocolate cookies and macaroons. They have all been delicious. If you are remotely nearby this place you should stop in and grab something you won't be disappointed. I wish I was in the shop right now. But alas I'm on my couch in San Mateo planning my next trek out to the city and to the Fillmore Bakeshop
author: kirstenbb c.

description: Kind of stopped in here by accident. Stopped in and grabbed 2 chocolate chip pecan cookies. Yummmmm!  Really good!!
author: Ami S.

description:
this is a must!!!

I've only tried one macaron place before this (paulette's, or i guess it's called lette's now) and i thought that was pretty good but expensive, now this places macarons are helllllllla good. Delicately crispy shells with nice moist chewy inside,  but on the down side, the filling was kind of over powering with the chocolate macarons and the champagne chocolate macaron is for someone who likes the taste of champagne cus it's very strong, My favorite would have to be the Green tea, and pistachio, my sister also said the lemon was amazing

I also had the "princess cake" which is this cake with green fondant on it, it was very good, not too sweet, and nice and creamy, the texture of the cake was some what like a tiramisu but thicker, and was nice and moist. I usually don't like fondant but this green one was exceptional, maybe it wasn't fondant but it had the same consistancy.

The quiche was good too, i don't know if i got a little after taste because of something i ate before it (i had some fish) but it left a little bitter after taste.

but in general YOU MUST COME BY AND TRY THIS PLACE. the workers are nice and helpful but on the downside there are only two tables so if those are occupied you don't have a place to sit down and enjoy your goodies.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Store was clean and cute.
Service was super friendly.
Macaroon was yum. (blood orange)
author: Marie H.

description: This bakeshop can do no wrong in my mind.  They are always making new delights, and today's treat was called a Bagel Bomb, which WAS the bomb!  Delicious bacon and chive cream cheese stuffed inside a soft bagel-like pretzel.  Yum!  Their Bronuts and Kronuts are also out of this world.  I love this place!  Wish I could give it six stars instead of five!  :D
author: Terri L.

description: I visit the Fillmore Bakeshop about twice a month, sometimes more if I am in the neighborhood. I started going there for the macaroons, but ended up loving their baked goods. I love their ham and cheese croissant, morning roll, and specialty cookies.
author: Mars F.

description:
Yay, Patisserie Delanghe has been reincarnated and improved!  The princess cake lives on, as delicious as ever.  The butter croissants are amazing.  The coffee is great.  The place has been remodeled and the seating area is much more inviting.  The whole place looks elegant and cosmopolitan now.  And best of all, grouchy Mr. Delanghe has been replaced with the charming Elena and her father Doug, and the equally charming wait staff (especially Claire and Yuddy).

Since they re-opened I've become a regular, even though I live in the Marina.  It's worth it to me to walk up a couple of miles round trip (including one big hill) to get my pastries here.  Plus, I can justify some of those calories :-)  I bring my dog and go sit with her in the park at the end of Cottage Row down the block (between Bush and Sutter) while I scarf down the goodies.

So far I've been working my way through their offerings and I have yet to find anything I don't absolutely LOVE.  Their danish are absolutely delicious.   I had a cream cheese/blueberry danish today that was wonderful.  The princess cake - Elena cut me a huge slice today from an actual cake (they had run out of the individual slices) and it was amazing - moist, flavorful, dense.  For those who don't know, it's the very definition of "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts" - white cake, whipped cream, custard, raspberry jam, all layered together and covered by this amazing moist pale green marzipan shell.  I don't particularly like any of these ingredients (except the custard) - but put them all together and somehow it works beautifully.

What else is great?  The bread pudding - they rotate the flavors.  I love the chocolate/banana and the boysenberry.  Their morning buns are like pastry cocaine.  The cookies are also wonderful.  I'll update when I've sampled more things - I tend to find a couple of things I like and stick with them, so it might be a while!

When I don't have my dog with me, I try to score one of the two tables in the sunny window and sit there to have my coffee and pastry.  Until now, I almost always get my coffee in "to go" (paper) cups even when I plan to stay, because I normally don't like the cups that cafes serve their coffee in - they're too thick, and the china seems to suck all the heat out of the coffee (unless they warm it up with hot water first, as they do at Peet's).  However, the china cups at Fillmore BakeShop are just perfect.  They're a lovely pale aqua blue, to match the plates and napkins, with thin rims.  Somehow, the experience of drinking coffee out of these cups makes the coffee taste even better.  And their silverware is so nice - shiny, heavy in your hand.  It elevates the "eat in" experience to me.  I may have to actually buy this same flatware and dishware to have at home!!!

The coffee is also the best, hands down, that I've had in any cafe in San Francisco.  Better than Peet's, better than Blue Bottle.  It's by a company called La Colombe.  

I haven't tried the chocolates yet but they're works of art - Elena's father makes them.

The pair of them have an amazing eye - the entire place has been transformed into this elegant space where everywhere you look, there is something gorgeous in front of you.

Yeah, I'm a fan - can you tell?
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Homemade macaroons were best we've had in SF!: 
-- soft center with lightly crispy outside. 
-- The variety of flavors were all well executed- blood orange, almond, chocolate, vanilla.
Service was friendly... will return.

Only down-check is the espresso is made here with a push-button brewer.
author: John B.

description:
I adore this bakery... and I am one picky customer! They always have a wonderful assortment of treats to choose from, all of which are delightful in their own way and their customer service is fantastic!
Pay attention to the weekend specials - especially the cronuts because this is the one bakery out here that has nailed the texture of this elusive mouth watering croissant/doughnut hybrid (every bit as sinful as it sounds). 
Their cakes are some of the best I've had! I placed an order for a couple quarter sheet cakes for a recent party and the results exceeded my expectations - and I have consumed an awful lot of cake in my time!Elena really listened to what I wanted and delivered two of the most amazing cakes I've ever consumed... The first, a chocolate cake with salted caramel mousse which melted on my tongue and got rave reviews from everyone at the party and the second, a white chiffon with raspberry custard, both of which were slathered with the perfect amount of light, fluffy, buttercream frosting - the kind that doesn't leave that unpleasant film in your mouth you might encounter in a bakery that didn't put such wonderful ingredients, and care, into their products. This second cake is dripping in nostalgia as it has been my favorite birthday cake for my entire life and I can honestly say that it was the BEST possible outcome.
You have to stop by this hidden gem and see what's hiding inside - it won't disappoint.
author: Holden L.

description: Came to SF with a group of girls for a bachelorette party. I decided to get up early and head the the bake shop for quiche, and of course the Cronut. The line was around the corner, and worth the wait. Every bite was everything you could ever want. Flaky, buttery, sweet and savory. The spinach and mushroom quiche was just as delicious. A must try for anyone in the area :)
author: Lindsay M.

description:
ENORMOUS macarons. 

Unfortunately, they were just mediocre.  The texture wasn't quite right - I think it was too dry, and the flavor wasn't evenly distributed - almost like the batter needed some more time in the Kitchenaid. 

I really wanted to like this place. Their boxes for the dessert had the cutest logo and it looked so posh.  It just wasn't meant to be... for you and me.
author: Lisa L.

description: When I popped in, it was in the middle of Saturday afternoon, so it looked like some locals had already popped in and ravaged the most desired goods.  That being said, the colorful display of macs as everyone has been posting about was really nice, and they have a nice variety of sweets!
author: Mel G.

description:
Came here because I saw this article on 7x7 magazine mentioning about the macarons.  While we were there, we picked up a quick lunch.  I had the spinach mushroom focaccia and it was really good.  I really like it a lot and the portion is super huge.   

As for the Macaron, I was a little disappointed.  Yes, they were huge, but the shell was just too too soft.  To the point when you bite, the whole thing cracks.  Friends bought one of each flavor available and I had the Salted Caramel.  It lacked the sea salt part in the caramel.  Very unevenly mixed.  Only one tiny part of it was where you tasted the salt part.  The other was just caramel.  Kinda what I expected.

Will not come back for the Macaron but definitely will be back for the Focaccia.
author: Doraemon T.

description: I live above this shop and it's been a blessing and a curse. I love walking down for a sweet afternoon snack (try the triple choc cookie or caramel macaroon). The curse is on my waistline. The service is always friendly. They also have a huge selection of breakfast pastries, cookies and cakes. I'm personally not a cronut fan bc they are too greasy. The Saturday flavors are creative though. If you are in the area and need a pick me up but don't want to pay 6 bucks for yogurt at fraiche, stop in here!!
author: Ariana P.

description: Okay... after reading reviews from fellow yelpers i decided to go and try out this bakery  to satisfy my sweet tooth cravings. I kept on seeing reviews raving about their macaroons and the princess cake. The macaroons to me were good.. but i've had better. The macaroon itself was a little too crunchy and airy to me. I enjoyed the filling more. I got three of their macaroons from the selection that they had and my personal favorite was the pistachio. And then there's the princess cake. It was super moist and tasted like it really was a cake for a princess :) I would definitely go back for that slice of heaven.. but not for the macaroons.
author: Mertani G.

description: Visiting San Francisco from Arkansas. I'm an avid baker so I had to try some bakeries while in Cali. I've never had a macaroon before, only whoopie pies. I enjoyed their texture, the harder outside with a nice soft chewy inside. I had the raspberry and coconut. Both were very good. Coconut was my favorite though :)
author: Robert H.

description: All I can say is get the Princess cake!! It is soo good!
author: Matthew L.

description:
I finally let myself go in here the other day. It always looks so cute and tempting but never went in. 

I walked out with two raspberry macaroons and a slice of princess cake. The raspberry macaroons had a delightful center but the first bite sent crumbs everywhere and it just got worse from there. Way too messy for me. The princess cake was one of the prettier slices I've seen. It was good, not the best that I've had but not bad.

I'd go back to try some of their other items if I am in the area. The service was friendly and answered all of my questions about the different flavors of macaroons.
author: Erica C.

description: Excellent bakeshop! Oatmeal raisin cookie was a delight. Also tried a piece of the berry pie - yummy! Staff super friendly too. Awesome late afternoon snack stop
author: Manish V.

description: I was blessed with 2 "cronuts" aka D's Nuts (apparently) by my lovely MIL. Hubby and I loved the cinnamon sugar one and we ate this cold, too. It was probably made in the AM and we ate it in the evening. YUM!! Would I wait an hour on a Sat @ 9a - hells no, but there's not much I would wake up for.
author: Freckles H.

description: Favorite macaron place in sf. Lived in the city for 4 years and would come here almost once a week for relaxing weekends on Fillmore st. with a macaron and latte! Highly recommended!
author: W D.

description:
A new bakeshop I encountered a few months ago. When they first opened you could tell they were new and still trying to get things in order. That said I am always in support of family owned businesses - and loved the father/daughter dynamic duo.  

My first visit - You must try their macaroons that are ridiculously good. There was so many to choose from I bought all their flavors and still to this day can't decide which is my favorite.

My second visit - I heard that the Princess cake was really good. I went in and purchased that as well as their handmade chocolate truffles.  Their truffles are a bit pricey but I have to say - worth every penny for that one bite of chocolate goodness!  I also purchased some of their pastries - chocolate croissant, chocolate chip cookie and their bread pudding.  

Today was my third visit - Their featured cupcake of the day was their German Chocolate Cupcake! It looked so good. I purchased it for a client and she was so excited and said she loved every bite of it! 

Fillmore Bakeshop's fresh baked pastries are amazing and not only that their presentation is great and their customer service is top notch! Family owned and operated I believe is the way to go - they're more hands on and you can see they have fun at what they do...  

I'd come more often but my waistline would definitely hate me!
author: Caroline C.

description: Can I give this place 6 stars? :) Fillmore bakeshop is awesome, I'm addicted to their Cronuts! I have to have them at least once a week. The chocolate chip pecan cookies are the best in the world. How do I know this? because I don't really like chocolate chip cookies normally, but I LOVE the ones they make here. Ridiculous. I'm fasting right now so I'm drooling while I'm writing this review. I also order cakes from here once in a while and the Mango/Passion Fruit was a hit at the last bday party. I just wished they made Bread :/ BUT.. Cronuts more than make up for it! Doug and Elena (owners) are also super nice people so stop by, grab some pastries/coffee and enjoy!.
author: hanzal M.

description: Bought a princess cake for my wife and daughter.  They loved it so much that I had to go back for more.  Their coffee was delicious and the staffs were very friendly. I would love to go there for my morning coffee every day.
author: The L.

description:
Awesome. Had the Salted Chocolate Caramel Cake. I had 3 gym rats with 5% body fat tell me they "didn't want any." Then I cut them each a slice. They took one bite each and ended up eating the whole cake within 15 minutes.

That sounds like a ringing endorsement to me.
author: Niko Z.

description: Came here just to get pastries.  Walked by and smelled so good!  Got the blueberry cream cheese danish, almond croissant, and boysenberry danish.  The danishes were crispy and light and great.  Almond croissant was probably my favorite.  It has a surprise chocolate filling.  Mmmmm.  After I ordered I heard someone ordered a cronut here.  I didn't know they sold those otherwise I would have tried it :(.  Next time I guess!
author: Lizzie C.

description: Fantastic apple pie that is perfectly done, with the flaky crust on the outside and the crunchy apple and a well balanced flavored filling on the inside. Croissants are buttery and flaky - just like those in France! Not to forget the friendly and great service.
author: mimi n.

description: This place is so so sooo cute. I saw it from across the street and i wanted to go in! So i did and saw that it was a cute little bakery, everything was so colorful and adorable! I loove macarons, so i decided to buy one. They have some of the biggest and poofiest macarons i've ever seen! Usually they're flat like a little sandwich, but not over hereee! they're puff balls man! But it was so cute so whateves, i usually like the smooth chewy texture inside, but this was different. since it was big, the shell broke apart very easily and it got kinda messy. the shell to filling portion wasn't right, because the shells were huuge and the filling was very little. i felt like i couldn't even taste it, but still a very adorable place! maybe i'll try something else there. i really want to like it ):
author: Bernice F.

description:
GREEN TEA MACAROONS. These are little heavenly delights. Slightly crispy on the outside and soft in the inside with a sweet green tea flavor. They are SO GOOD. 

I'm not as big of a fan with the other flavors, but with the green tea macaroons they made them just right.
author: Denise W.

description: They also have great focaccia.  Try the jalepeno if you like a little kick.  Only available on Saturdays though, which is good because it seems like I only go there on Saturdays.
author: Lorraine Y.

description:
The best Stollen ever. 

I have tried lots of Stollen - lots of very good Stollen - though this hands down is my favorite. Not too sweet, full of wonderful dried fruit, and hazelnuts (!). 

I am considering driving all the way over there from the East Bay so Ic an package one of these and ship it to my German Grandmother who resides in the Midwest. 

Great job bakers!
author: Kristine V.

description:
Newly opened- bought over a different bake shop.

Goods: I tried a slice of their Strawberry Surprise cake ($3.75) and it was AMAZING! The different layers of chocolate provided great textures for my mouth and the strawberry mousse was heavenly. Will definitely return for more baked goods!

Service: very friendly!
author: linh d.

description:
3 & 1/2 stars

I picked up 5 macarons (strawberry, coconut, pistachio, almond, and blood orange) when I was here last time.

I can't say that all of the macarons tasted good - I only liked the blood orange and pistachio. Never had a blood orange macaron before but it was really good.
My least favorite would be the almond; it didn't really tasted like almond and it was waaaaay too sweet.

One of the things I didn't like about these macarons was the texture. Just like many macarons out there, the shells are hard and crunchy. I prefer the texture to be a little more on the soft and chewy side.

Overall, these little cookies are decent and I would definitely give them a try again.
author: Aeris W.

description: Okay, I am going to have to check out the hype on these darn macaroons soon, but this place gets 5 stars for the multitude of other goodies that I discovered this past  Sunday.    and OMG the danishs , wow!! gotta try those, absolutely delish
author: Ferdinand B.

description:
Maybe it was because I was in the shop after 3pm, but the croissant and danish I brought home were hard and very dry.  The croissant was flaky, but I detected no hint of butter in it.  No buttery taste in the danish, either.  

Many of the treats looked splendid, the service was friendly and efficient.  Lots of action behind the counter with lots of splendid looking kitchen gadgets.

I'll try and again and hope for an upgrade to my review.  Right now, right square on the fence of meh with hopes for improvement.
author: Donna H.

description: Love their macarons.  They're more flavorful (the strawberry was crazy good) than I've had in LA.  Sadly, they don't travel well as they don't have decent boxes for them.
author: Katy T.

description: My biggest gripe is that I ordered their quiche thinking that it was vegetarian, and was unfortunately surprised with bacon inside. There was no name or description indicating there would be bacon. The quiche was warm on the outside, but cold in the inside which made it worse. Had to ask them to reheat it, and even then, it was not good. Their lattes are decent and served in really cute cups. If I come back, it would only be for convenience and their baked goods.
author: Mo A.

description:
Fillmore Bakeshop I really wanted to love you.  I mean it, I really did.  You are a small local business, have awesomely nice workers, and you sell macarons. The only problem was the macarons were not anything like I expected.  

When I walked in I saw the macarons sitting behind a glass window just waiting to be eaten by me and before I could even say anything I was already being helped by a extremely nice older man. I quickly picked out 6 different flavors of macarons and was on my way.  As I walked out I pulled one out, bit into it and to my horror it was dense, chewy and not what a macaron is supposed to be like at all. I chalked it up to me just buying them and them still being a little cold so I waited a bit to try the rest, but even after waiting they still had the same texture.  I mean they were good cookies don't get me wrong, but they just weren't macarons.  Macarons are supposed to be light and delicious and break easily under my teeth.  I should not have to make an effort to bite through my macarons. 

Well maybe it was a bad day and since the workers were all friendly and I tend to be in the area a lot anyways I will come back and give you guys another chance.  Until then 3 stars is good because like i said I really want to like you.
author: Domingo D.

description: I've become a loyal fan of this sweet little bakeshop over the past several months. The goods are great, the atmosphere is intimate and cozy, and the people who work here are friendly. If you're going to splurge on a sweet treat on Fillmore, do it here!
author: Molly P.

description: I love pie, and this bakery has it going on!  The season is over for peaches, but this place has the best d@m peach pie I've ever eaten. Looking forward to their pumpkin pie this Fall :)
author: Patrick W.

description: Macaroons were dry and crusty. It was before noon so they must have sold me yesterday's or last weeks. Very disappointed.
author: Christine G.

description: So good - if they have them when you are there try the cronut and the morning roll or the pretzel bread. Amazing. Staff are always busy, but try to keep the line moving.
author: Nicole J.

description: I just learned that this bakery is no longer owned by an older cranky Frenchman but in fact was turned over two years ago to a nice girl and her Dad! Anyone with a sweet tooth should rush here now and try her pecan pie bar before the word gets out and they raise the price. I hail from the south and have had my fair share of pecan pie and I give that creation two thumbs up!
author: Jason S.

description:
I came here earlier today to kill two birds with one stone: to satisfy my month-long yearning for french macaroons and because my boyfriend and I had some spare time on an early Sunday morning. It's a quaint, little bakery that has a relaxing atmosphere, emphasis on the little. The indoor seating contains only two small coffee tables and a total of 6 seats. I don't believe there was any outdoor seating. The daughter of the bakery boxed up my order in a cute, little, blue box. This cutesy box was an offset to her hostile disposition. Not one word of "Good morning", "Thank you", or even a response to my boyfriends, "Thank you" upon our departure was uttered throughout our 30-minute stay. 

I purchased 4 macaroons to taste: vanilla, green tea, lemon, and mocha. The sizes of all four was fair and looked very puffed up. The outer coating was very crispy/crunchy.
