The inside was chewy and more than one of the four contained air pockets. In addition to the disappointment of being greeted with emptiness when biting into a macaroon, all four were very, very sweet. The vanilla and green tea literally tasted as if it were coated with a light dusting of confectioners sugar. The vanilla and green tea were not very true to flavor whereas the lemon had the slightest hint of citrusy-tang. The mocha was probably the best in terms of flavor. Overall, I don't think I would be returning here to purchase french macaroons for approximately $2 apiece. I do not recommend the macaroons despite the popularity of them on yelp. The price to size ratio makes it a deal, but the taste and air pockets do not. On a brighter note, the pastries and cookies looked quite delectable!
author: Joanna J.

description:
Macarons, macarons, macarons!

On my way back to the hotel from the Fillmore Jazz fest, I could not pass by here again. I had to get the Macarons. 

I picked up a half a dozen, trying all the pertanent flavors. 

Next time I will be trying the cakes.
author: Germaine N.

description: Fillmore Bakeshop is known for its big, flavorless macarons. Fork over some cash and get your grainy, crumbly, over-dyed macarons here. Your mouth will be dry and your nephrons will be...   whatever color your macarons were.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Out of towner here, dropped in while strolling the neighborhood.  Very friendly service provided coffee, a slice of apricot almond tart, and a couple macarons.  Coffee was decent.  The tart was inedible.  Crust was soggy to the bottom and the custard above it tasted like the sugar was left out. Clearly nobody tasted the apricots used for this tart.  It was flavorless and squishy, leaking it's tasteless nectar throughout.

My companion enjoyed the macarons which I did not taste.  He enjoyed them, but I was not inspired. The artificial garish colors reminded me of children"s fingerpaint.

The kind guy cleared out table and noticed I had not eaten the tart and asked it all was okay.  I answered politely with candor and he replaced it with several cookies.  I tasted each and tossed them.  Not worth the calories.  the second star was for the kind service.
author: Joel D.

description: Very good pastries, if you want a taste of French chocolate croissant that's where you need to go! Everything is fresh and homemade! The only thing I dislike are the macaroons, it's not their speciality! They are good but not the best in town! But pastries are delicious! Their pies are also good but not very Frenchy ;) !
author: Valentine C.

description: at 1.95 for a macaron,  the price is steep but well worth it. tried the pistachio, saffron orange, raspberry, chocolate, caramel, rose, and a couple of other ones. all of them were good. some looked bigger than others. the cookie itself had a nice chewy texture the way i like it. the fillings were oh so delectable. i loved how it wasn't overpowering, but perfect. i will be back for more macarons and to try some of their cakes!
author: Stella J.

description: Came here after going to the Bun Mee grand opening. Had me some macaroons. All the cakes and macaroons look like they were made with love and have consistent sizes. I loved the pistachio macaroon. It was a great snack after lunch. We also had the princess cake which tasted super fresh. The cake was moist and soft and the custard was yummy. Will be back again if I'm ever in the hood!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
After lunch, we strolled down the street to check out some of the shops. Of course when I saw "bakeshop" my eyes widened and had to take a peek at their goodies.

I was ecstatic to see macarons behind the glass and of course had to get one of each. These babies are extra small and were pretty pricey. More than paulette's I believe and does not come in cute packaging. 

I am happy to say that I enjoyed all of the flavors though! Texture of the cookie and filling was great. Saffron was my favorite! I love macarons!!
author: Stine H.

description: I am a huge fan of this bakery. They invited me to cheat on my diet with them, at any time. The service is without an equal in the neighborhood. All of the baked goods are fabulous, and it seems to me, less expensive.
author: Linda S.

description: Love love love this place!! Great, fresh, and delicious sweets of all sorts sold here!! Wonderful family owned bakery with sweet service to match their sweets ;) come here and be happy!!
author: Monica G.

description:
Best Napoleons in the Bay Area (and trust me, I've tried them all...literally)!  Best personal service and custom order as well... thank you, Elena!  Your years of pastry study & training in Switzerland has  paid off and won you a permanent spot in my heart and tummy!    

Our story:  My husband's mother is famous to our family and friends for her homemade Napoleons, and for our wedding, we wanted to pay tribute to them.  In order to honor their fabulousness, we did taste-offs of all the best Napoleons in the Bay Area from all the top bakeries and Yelper recs (I realize, not a very diet-friendly pre-wedding exercise, but it was well worth it and now I've done the legwork for the rest of you!).   It came down to two Napoleons after a couple months of searching:  One from the North Bay that LOOKED artistically impeccable & tasted good, and Elena's at the Fillmore Bakeshop, which looked more like my mother-in-law's (ie. homemade) and whose custard was out of this world.  Winner of our taste-off:  Fillmore Bakeshop!  

We discovered that Napoloens that look perfect (like our 2nd place winner), don't necessarily taste perfect, as the custard is supplemented with whipped cream in order to give it a thickness that will shape the cut squares, well, perfectly.  Factory appearance means factory taste to some extent, so don't be fooled by bakeries that look like they have perfect pastries... they are often missing that individual effort and care.  Fillmore Bakeshop's Napoleon LOOKS BEAUTIFUL TOO, but it doesn't sacrifice taste and quality for appearance sake, and is made there on the spot with family love and quality.  It's most authentic and European, not American manufactured.  Elena & the Bakeshop use a true custard, with more expensive ingredients than whipped topping, but without adding to it's very reasonable price.  The result:  The MOST amazing custard on the planet!!  

Elena is the most fun and enthusiastic baker around.  She was so flexible with creating a custom order for us (for example, my mother-in-law uses some cherry juice in the frosting, and Elena was happy to do the same for our wedding)!  She knew how much we loved her custard, so she put some extra into ours for the wedding per request, and also put some extra frosting on the top because we mentioned how much we love it.   It was the first and fastest thing to go at the wedding, and people were raving it about it all night and still ask about the Napoleons a couple months later.  Fantastic prices to boot!
author: Tej A.

description: Awesome owner, great staff and the best Coconut Macaroons and Pies in town!
author: Daniel S.

description: SUPER friendly service. french macarons are good- depending on the flavor, some were chewy...which is what i love. others were kind of hard :( (sorry i cant remember which flavors i got) i remember chocolate and almond were what i'd go back for. got a chocolate cookie (posted in pictures) that i didnt really like, not very sweet. will be back for the chocolate and almond flavored macarons!
author: Denise L.

description: We had lunch at Fresca and decided to stop by the bakeshop for some dessert to go. I ended up leaving with eight mini macaroons and a slice of their raspberry and peach bread pudding. Bread pudding was good, but the macaroons were much better! The flavors definitely come through unlike other macaroons I've had where they look colorful but lack in taste. We got root beer, blood orange, passion fruit, lemon, blackberry, rose, chocolate and strawberry - all equally tasty!
author: Cindy T.

description:
Lovely neighborhood bakery.  The display cases are filled with a great collection of pastries-from danishes to macaroons to napoleons.  They also have some great looking mini eclairs and and cakes.  Grabbed some coffee too-so it was a like a mini Parisian morning.

Everything was fresh tasting even though we went at 2pm.  

Definitely going to make it a weekly stop.
author: AJ L.

description:
Fillmore Bakeshop is hands down my favorite bakery in SF. They have the lighest, smoothest macaroons.. and not to mention their cakes are amazing too. I've been to a bunch of different places for macaroons, and have to say these are truly special. 

PS. The staff are super nice too!
author: Matt D.

description:
This review is based soley on their macaroons! WOWZERS, yes I'm a fan indeed. Never had macaroons like this before, pistachio, mango, passion fruit, coffee....the list goes on.

I stepped inside this bakery with all intentions of buying the bread pudding special, I was lured in from the posted sign outside but as soon as I seen the macaroons I forgot all about everything, sweet tooth def took over.

I will be back to try out other pastries, unfortunately not on Mondays they're closed *sad face
author: tiffany d.

description: My friend and I were in the neighborhood, and in search for cupcakes.  We came across the Fillmore Bakeshop.  There was not a cupcake in site.  We were told they were out of them.  This bakery's specialty is more about macaroons, which was my other choice since people seemed to rave about them on Yelp.  We both tried the almond chocolate macaroons.  Which was not too impressive.  They were too dry.  I'm not sure if they were from the day before or if they seem to dry up quickly?? I've had amazing macaroons before, and unfortunately Fillmore Bakeshop didn't do it for me.
author: Dannash M.

description:
*Chocolate Chip Cookie (with some kind of nut):  Yum!  I like chewy chocolate chip cookies but this is really good for a crunchy cookie, and has lots of chocolate chips.
*Hazelnut Macarons: Yum!  Fluffy, light, sweet macarons!  Not like the typical macarons that are more on the solid side.

I have to go back to try the rest.  Good little shop in the Fillmore that I just happened to stumble into.
author: R S.

description:
So i have been on a total macaron hiatus for abour 2 months or so... After lunch on Saturday the bf  suggested we take a walk to Fillmore bakeshop (which was just down the street, then up a semi hill.. ) okay, i'll walk to get some yummi macarons no problem!! 
This bakery is cute, but busy!! There were a couple of people in front of us ordering their goodies which gave me plenty of time to look at all the wonderful slightly larger (yes, you read that right no anorexic mararons sold here, just slightly plump macaron's just staring out into the world from their display case waiting to be bought). Everyone in the bakery is friendly. From the first moment you walk in, you are greeted by someone. 
Not only does this bakery sell macarons but they also have assorted cakes,pie,bread pudding, peach-raspberry and strawberry-rhubarb,pound cake along with Quiches (check to see what the speical of the day is), assorted breads. coffee and teas. 

When it was finally our turn, we decided on getting a small amount of macarons. At $1.95 each, it wasnt to bad considering the size of those suckers!! 
And let me tell you, the wait was worth it!! As soon as we walked back to our car we dug into the box!! The rose macaron that i ate first was super mild tasting, not like all the other rose ones i've had before (where it tasted like i inhaled a rose petal and not a macaron). It had a subtle taste with a hint of rose, and to top it off it had an extra crunchiness to it. I wanted to try the lemon one, but that was being saved for the trip home the next day! And yes, i am happy to say that the lemon was well worth the wait too... Two words to describe it: Zesty and Delish!! Plus it wasnt dryed out on the second day (score).

This bakeshop is truly hidden gem in SF that i cant wait to go back to!!
author: Sarah A.

description: I loved the macaroons from this place (both green tea and passionfruit were great).  Latte was good too.  I'll have to try one of their baked goods next time:)
author: J K.

description:
I wish I could give them a better rating, the gentlemen who helped me was very nice and patient with my crack-like addiction to getting the right macaron flavors, I think there was around 12 flavors??

I was in the area with mi madre after a not so delicious lunch at the Thai Stick up the street (the one on O'Farrell was much better); I was hoping to end my misfortune by finding this high-rated bakery on my app.  

Arrived at the bakery with a friendly greeting from the worker and a beautiful display of baked goods and a separate display for the giant macarons.  The size of the bakery is moderate and offered a couple tables to just sit, eat, and look at all the rich shoppers that can afford to shop regularly at the boutiques nearby.

My mom had the bread pudding with some nice fruit (forgot what it was though LOL) was very smooth and focused more on the custardy texture than sweetness (I'm a sugar bomb girl so this took a little getting used to),  and the corners offered a nice crunch .  The blueberry muffin was very soft and fresh, had worse and have better, but it was still very good.

The low star rating is STRICTLY for the macarons, I'd actually give it 2 stars and one extra star for the nice service.  I knew in the back of my mind those macarons looked too big and poofy to be soft and tender in the center [***UPDATE.. I'd give it 3 if you leave it sitting for one day & a 3.5 for 2-3 days (softens the macaron a little bit**, but if you want to eat it the day of.. the following is what you should expect].  They had a deal, where you buy 12, and you get one free; my lard ass went for it and got flavors I felt safe with (pistacio, honey, irish coffee, lemon, passion fruit, pb & chocolate, almond, vanilla, you get the picture) and boy did it go downhill from there.  Biting into their macaron is like biting into a mix b/w a meringue and an over-baked chewy cookie--which is what I would NOT want in a french macaron.  Actually, I'd never want it T_T... Too much crumbling, hard chewing, and frowning.  I believe they're using too much egg whites and sugar, and/or overbaking.  And the filling did not offer any support (or apologies) either, reminds me of room temperature butter between two graham crackers.  I'm also very partial to overly colored things in general, so their overly bright colors where not in the least bit appetizing (you could tell I was really eating with my blind eyes that day) I'm saying this with a heavy heart because I wanted to enjoy it very much, but I couldn't, I kept going back to the box, trying a flavor, then putting it back frowning.  Thank God their macaroons prices weren't too much off the roof (13 priced around $23?)  I would have been super depressed if I paid over 30 for this.

I've paid more for smaller but had amazing experiences.. another good learning experience that bigger & cheaper isn't always (or is rarely ever) better.
author: Iralyn J.

description:
I LOVE how you can see right into their kitchen and watch all of the baking action!  I also love how it's family run by daughter and dad, feels good to support fellow small businesses.  Daughter was really friendly and described a bunch of items when I had trouble deciding.

Very important- decent coffee and fresh baked goods galore!  Had their chocolate dipped hazelnut cookie- very nutty & crispy and just the way I like it!  My son gave a thumbs up to the pumpkin shaped cookie (chocolate in the middle).
author: Judy K.

description: Just came in after having lunch at Woodhouse Fish Co. Had the salted caramel macaron. It was light and delicious, almost as good as we had at Laduree in Paris. My husband had the Triple Chocolate Chip cookie which was nice and crispy outside and chewy on the inside.  As good as my own.
author: Lisa C.

description:
We dropped by this place after eating some frozen yogurt at Fraiche as this bakery looks so inviting! As a baker and a sweet tooth, of course I cannot ignore the macarons ($1,95 each). They do have quite a wide range of flavors but the quality is not stable. We had basically one each from every flavor to try. The first bite of the raspberry one was really strange as a macaron is not supposed to be that dry crispy and it does have huge air hole, you technically don't taste almond but crunchy sugar! But the others taste quite okay, the blackberry filling was not the most pleasant one. 
I gave 3 stars because the staff seems friendly.
I'm still searching for the best bakery in town!
author: Olivia T.

description: This review is based only on their D's Nutz (knock off of a Cronut). I was referred to this place for their cronuts. Having tried the actual cronuts in NYC (Dominique Ansel Bakery), I was excited from all the great yelp reviews. Obviously, these great yelp reviews were from people that have never had the real thing. These things were basically just a very doughy donut that will set you back $2.75ea. I might come back here to try some of their other pastry items, but definitely stay away from their D's Nuts!
author: Jeffrey L.

description: This place is made of love.  Everything I've tasted, from the macarons to the bread pudding tastes like the bakers added lots of love.  My favorite is the rose marcaron or the honey lavender.  I love floral flavors... not everyone does.  I recently just tried some delightful bread pudding which contained a berry compote.  My all time favorite is the salted caramel cake, which is to die for!  Try this place!  Why?  Because it's not a chain, the employees seem to love what they do and are happy to make recommendations, the service is great and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Irenka P.

description: The Fillmore Bakeshop is the best bakery in San Francisco! Their products are made fresh daily, they use the freshest ingredient and the highest quality of products. Doug and Elena are the owners, great caring people. I have ordered many cakes and macarons and all were delicious. I think I have tried every items they make and loved them all. I am very passionate about this place, did I mention pricing...very reasonable. Oh BTW, the best coffee in SF! Yee Haw.
author: Joy P.

description: Super duper cute bakery.  I was drooling over all the pastries in an unabashed way. I finally settled on sampling a couple of their macrons - which were huge compared to the teensy macarons you see elsewhere (think sand dollar compared to a quarter). The chocolate peanut butter and salted caramel were delightful though the choco PB slightly wins on taste.  I will diligently make my way through the other flavors and report back :)
author: Amy N.

description:
This is a terrific bakeshop, now one of my favorites in San Francisco. Below is a list of what I had and what I thought of it:

Peach Pie: I need to mention this thing right up front because it is absolutely the best peach pie I have ever had. I got the last slice of the day and it was sitting on a plate, by itself, looking pretty pathetic really. But when I took it home and ate the first bite my eyes opened up pretty wide. Best peach pie I ever had, hands down. Bonus points for keeping the skin on the peaches, which added that extra bit of naturalness that is lacking in other peach pies that I've tried.

Apple pie: Delicious. Apples still have crunch to them but not in a raw way... just cooked perfectly. The crust was just the right amount of thickness and tasted good.

Blood Orange macaron and the Passion Fruit Macaron: Good flavor. Beautiful appearance. Kind of missing that macaron chewiness when you bite down on it.

Peanut Butter Macaron: I'm not a peanut butter desserts kind of person but I still enjoyed this one, my wife liked it more than me. This had the right sort of chewy bite that I love out of my macarons. 

Coffee/Irish Cream (?): I honestly forgot what the exact flavor was but it was probably one of their most popular as it was almost all gone! Some chewiness in the bite but not much. Flavors were really frikkin good.

Over all though, a well deserved four stars. The inside is so comfortable, maybe from the decor but especially from the people working there. Very inviting and makes me want to come back often.
author: Davin A.

description: I got the 6inch mango passion fruit mousse cake.  It was beautifully decorated with chocolates and berries.  I'm usually not a big fan of mousse cakes but each bite was exquisite.  I couldn't wait to have seconds!   The mousse and cake proportion was perfect, it had 2 layers of mousse and 3 layers of cake.  Usually, the mousse cakes I've had before has a huge layer of mousse with really little cake (way too much mousse for my preference).  This was a little on the tart side since it was topped with lemon curd, but I thought the tanginess was good and not overly powering.  I'll be back to try their other cakes and baked goods!  Service was also excellent.
author: Veronica N.

description: Delightful! I special ordered the best custom made creampuffs ever! Elena, the owner, was completely accommodating and even put freshly sliced strawberries in my creampuffs. They were hit at my event and everyone loved them! Thank you so much Fillmore Bakeshop!
author: Margarita G.

description: Incredibly warm and friendly staff here at Fillmore Bakeshop, and the cherry pie is to DIE for. Pair it with a latte for a nice treat.
author: Trav M.

description: I was crushed when I found out that Patisserie Delanghe had shut its doors back in 2010, then delighted to hear that another bakery would open in the same location. My family has not been disappointed. Fillmore Bakeshop provides excellent morning pastries, cookies, bars, and cakes and I regularly come up with excuses to go to that neighborhood just to stop by. The staff is friendly and happy to serve up their delicious treats. Elena, the owner, has created a great establishment.
author: Holly H.

description:
I am visiting from the pastry wasteland of Atlanta Georgia.  On my first jet-lagged morning, I stumbled on the Fillmore Bakeshop in search of a cup of coffee.  What a find!  You are greeted by nice people and a beautiful display of cakes, breads and pastry.  I settled on a blueberry and cream cheese pastry and a cup of coffee.  I was hooked.  Day 2, more coffee a wonderful light croissant.  I watched the line form for cronuts, but didn't have time to wait for this legendary treat.  Day 3, back for another fruit pastry and coffee.  As I was eating my breakfast, I saw them add a beautiful bread pudding to the display case.  Yup, I needed 2 of those.  I sneaked at taste and it is amazing!  Elena recognized me as having visited her store 3 days in a row.  She went out of her way to thank me for my business.  What's lovely lady.  And yes, I was able to score a cronut.  I now know why people wait in line for them-decadent!
Thanks Elana.  See you next trip.
author: Don F.

description: There I was, 18 weeks pregnant, without a bakery in the city who was willing to dye buttercream frosting pink or blue for a gender reveal party (I love San Francisco, I really do, but every once in awhile the East Coast in me just wants to rage against the machine a bit...I mean, REALLY?! Artificial dye for one cake was apparently just more than the organic, hippie dippy SF bakeries could handle). Enter Elena. It was like the 15th bakery I called and she was so NICE. When I explained the dye problem she was like, "Who the...??! No, I don't have time to be condescending, I'm running a business." I ordered the cake from her and actually ended up going with her suggestion to do a berry shortcake (raspberries and strawberries inside for a girl, blackberries and blueberries for a boy). The cake was BEAUTIFUL, we got a gazillion compliments both on how pretty it was but, more importantly, how delicious it was! That cake will live in our memories as when our little baby became our little girl, Violet. Will absolutely be back to them for her first birthday :)
author: Kathryn M.

description:
This bakery is ridiculous ... it is so good! The macarons are incredible. They taste like lil' delicious sandwich clouds. Best of all they don't seem mass produced and generic like many others in the city. Try the rose with its opalescent glaze or the mocha, hazelnut or blood orange. These are monster macarons not made for the faint of heart. You can't go wrong with any flavor you choose because it is all made with love you can taste in each bite!  

This bakery only gets better if you continue to explore! The salted carmel cake is incredible. Delicate, rich and perfect with a cup of coffee. Don't like coffee? Have tea with an orange shortbread cookie or 2. Uh-Mazing. And there is more waiting for you to discover beyond the bakery window. 

The best part of this shop is it has character complete with a wonderful owner who makes you feel like you are the most important customer. Elena has a genuine passion for food and you can taste and feel the difference when you walk in. Unlike the other attitude rich service at places like Miette. This is by far the best bakery in town! A must try!
author: Marina p.

description: Beautiful shop, friendly staff, and by far the best almond croissant I have ever had. Can't wait to go back and try something else!!!
author: Melanie L.

description: Stopped in after seeing the Princess cake sign in the window.  I was like, "What, they named a cake after me?!"  Anywho, passed on the cake because I just had to try the lavender honey macaroon.  Yum!  The perfect little treat after our bahn mi sammich up the block.  I'm looking forward to visiting again.
author: Felicia P.

description: My boyfriend told me that I needed to try this bakeshop because of their giant macarons, and we finally visited yesterday.  Many of their other baked goods looked delicious, including the fascinating "princess cake" that is covered with marzipan icing (something to try in the future!).  We ended up trying the pear and blood orange macarons.  The first we ate was the pear one, and it was light and subtle in flavor - a little too subtle because I could barely taste the pear.  The blood orange one was much better, with the perfect amount of tang and good orange flavor.  Flavors to try soon:  pistachio, blackberry, hazelnut, lemon, and vanilla!  My palate is very happy that we live near this place!
author: Can C.

description:
Happened to pass by this place seeking sweets & voila! Parisienne-macaroons, & a big variety of them. Hard to choose a flavor so picked: chocolate, strawberry, & blackberry (I think). Ate two out of three so far & they are pretty darn good. Would buy them from here again.

They also sell other goodies like florentine cookies, but I resisted only because I didn't want to overindulge in a single visit. 

Friend bought a slice of berry pie to go, but I would have also if we were eating there. Will try it next visit.
author: D L.

description: After an hours walk (Freakin droid naviagation) we made it to the Filmore. We could not check in to our hotel so we decided to rub elbows with a little gluttony....after all we did burn a s@#t load of calories trying to find this place. This place that was 2 blocks in the other direction from which that tramp sent us....let the indulging begin!!!! My daughter ordered a cinnamon roll,and I a piece of apple pie with a few macaroons to go for us to munch on later. My pie was delish and her cinnabun sweet and flakey. Ohhh Filmore you will see us before we depart,my taste buds love you but my thighs are flipping you off!!!!
author: Carolyn T.

description: This place rocks! We ordered a delicious cake here for a party and it was fabulous. And the staff and owners are very friendly and willing to go the extra mile to make things just as you want. We just ordered another cake for a big party coming up next week. Can't wait! PS: I do agree with other comments here re. the macarons... they are delicious!
author: Heidi C.

description: I absolutely love this place!  The macroons are amazingly good with so many flavors to choose from.  The rose flavor that is over the top.  Everything is so good!  The bread pudding is to die for.  Probably the best I have ever tasted.  If you need a cake try the salted caramel.  I  took it to a party and everyone raved about it.  Every cake I have tasted from them is delicious.  Plus they are beautifully decorated and worth every penny.   Not only do they have tasty treats, the owners Elena and Doug are the nicest people you will ever meet.   They always have a smile and will spend time getting to know their customers.  They will do everything in their power to customize your baked goods in a way that matches your needs. Something that is so rare these days!
author: Michele S.

description: Good coffee, fine pastry, the best staff! Thank you guys!
author: Vicky K.

description:
One of my FAV bakeries!!!!!
It easily encourages me to run 4 miles AROUND SF instead of taking a 2 mile bus to get there.  MM!  Will post more later
author: Cathy U.

description: We just had the salted caramel cake for the first time last week. This is the most amazing, mouth-watering deliciousness you can imagine. Creamy with just a touch of salt, not too sweet, just perfection. Six of us finished it in 10 minutes! Thank you Elena for waking up so early in the morning to bake for us!!
author: Jamie B.

description:
Super nice people working there....both the baker and the counterperson. When I was younger and would walk by and stick my face against the large windows to watch the previous baker work his magic, he'd always glare at me. But, that's probably because I was fogging up his windows with my icky child breath.
Anyhow, they "revamped" recently, and my mother and I decided to try their macarons since we, like the rest of the world, is on a macaron kick right now. Green tea and chocolate hazelnut, the later per suggestion of the baker himself.
Okay, so they were okay. Just okay. The texture was more crumbly than I like, less chewy in the middle, and the flavoring was not pure, but more simply "sugary" tasting. Having my first macaron at Paulettes makes any macaron I try after, that much more difficult to impress. However, I will be back to try their scrumptious looking bread pudding and cookies and butter lemon pound cake..and oh my. Many more things to taste test =]
author: jeddie k.

description:
If you don't want to waste an hour of your life reading about my gushing over the newly-opened Fillmore Bakeshop, I can cut it to just five words: 

Pistachio macaron-- get thee one. 

Standing dumbstruck on Fillmore two afternoons ago after sampling a bite of Fillmore Bakeshop's rose macaron, I realized I'll never be rich or thin. Not with my helplessly profound addiction to macarons, anyhow. And, without contest, Fillmore Bakeshop wins the prize for being the best enablers in the area. One bite of this macaron and I turned on my heel to run back for more.

The father-daughter proprietors of the new bakeshop, Doug and Elena Basegio (as I found out by the grace of fellow yelpers) are churning out laminated doughs and pâtes à choux like it's nobody's business. There are pies, shortbreads, adorably perfect chocolate chip cookies and various flavored (and classic) croissants all lined up along the right side of the display, and then your delicate little confections hang out to the left, with the princess cake reigning over all. Poppa Basegio's celebrated line of artisanal chocolates, Au Coeur des Chocolats (the palet d'or truffle is my favorite so far), is proudly put on display to enjoy along with all of the baked goods made in-house. Which are wonderful. Y. and I sampled mini eclairs and St. Honoré puffs. Both shells were slightly moister and more tender than most puffs I've had (perhaps more egg yolk? more butter?), and the latter's vanilla custard was spiked generously with rum, which punctuated the vanilla flavor nicely. I prefer a more wispy touch with the caramelized sugar for crunchier texture, but the flavor was superb.

But really, the crowning jewel of the bakery, for me, were the macarons. The shells have the wonderful fine-grained texture evident in the lack of lumps on the surface, and the fillings are intensely flavored, silky in texture but restrained in sugar. This is actually a noticeable trend in all of the Bakeshop's goods-- no more sugar than is necessary to bring out the sweetness in the ingredients and the final product itself-- and it's something that I really appreciate. The buttercream is smooth and feather-light in the almond, rose and pistachio macarons. I have no idea how Elena distills the flavors into these tiny little treats, but whatever magic it takes, I'll subscribe to it. The rose and pistachio macarons, especially, were so evocative of the real thing. I was seriously floored, and we ended up demolishing nine macs within an hour.

I never tried Patisserie Delanghe, so I cannot comment on whether or not this is an improvement, or if even it does justice to the history. But just for the sake of my pathetic, wallet-draining addiction to macarons, I hope the Basegios will be here for at least as long as the Delanghes were. Well, and they're super-duper nice. They don't have a sign put up in the front yet, but something tells me I'll find my way back.
author: Nuri K.

description:
I love everything about this place. 

Delicious cakes, cookies, and pies? Check. 
Crazy Delicious Macarons, some of the best in the city? Check. 
Neighborhood feel where a random older gentleman will consult you on his grandaughter's birthday cake? Check. 
Super wonderful owners who always say good morning? Check. 

Love, love, love.
author: M J.

description:
I work up the street from the Fillmore Bakeshop and recommend it to everyone. I've tried most everything from there and would like seconds on it all. If the cookies and coffee weren't enough to keep me coming back on my breaks, the super friendly owners really make it worth it. It's so nice to see a bakery who recognizes their neighborhood patrons and care so much about their business and their customers. 

And their peppermint bark is amazing!!!!
author: Lindsey G.

description:
I was a Patisserie Delanghe loyalist, but Doug and Elena have won me over. This father-daughter team turns out fantastic cookies and pastries. I've had the chocolate raspberry cake, the coconut macaroons, the more delicate French macarons, the German chocolate cupcake and the hazelnut cookies--all of which I'd buy again though the cookies are my favorites. I was kind of surprised that they had the guts to offer a princess cake--Delanghe's was the best in town--but theirs measures up beautifully. 

I also love Doug and Elena's creativity. There's a different cupcake every day and they're elegant enough to serve at a dinner party. Their Giants-cap cake was adorable. And they're always finding inspiration for new stuff. They seem to be having a ball running this shop.

Yes, there were some growing pains. The store's been open just a few weeks. But I've found Doug and Elena to be extremely interested in feedback and eager to make their customers happy. It's impossible to leave the shop without a smile. I recommend the Fillmore Bakeshop  wholeheartedly.
author: Amy B.

description: We just ate a few extraordinary cookies at the Fillmore Bakeshop.  The coconut macaron was steller.  The chocolate ganach and buttery spatebuche was amazing.  The father and daugher bakers were busy making fresh goodies for the shelves.  I love this place!
author: Liz Y.

description: Elena is amazing; her cakes are out of this world; the flavors are to die for and her design is ON FIRE!  Talk about customer service; I have not been spoiled with kindness in a long time - she is attentive, loving and talented!  FILLMORE BAKESHOP rocks!
author: Craig L.

description: I like this place. It was okay, but not my favorite. I brought the princess cake and it was good. (but really expensive. if it was that much i think it should be a little bit better.) I also got the macaroons. The passion fruit macaroon was good, (good flavor and taste) but it was kind of chewy... (kind of got stuck in my teeth. Yes, gross but true.)
author: Linda P.

description: Just had one of the best pastries ever.  If you didn't know it was possible to be "stunned" by a pastry... keep your eyes peeled for the "love bun."  I just sat in awe for about 3 minutes after eating this.  In two years of going there I have never seen it before... but holy crap that was good.
author: Tommy V.

description:
Friends of mine brought over a selection of their delicious macaroons for dessert and OH MY GOD! Blood Orange?  Yes.  Coffee?  Yes. Caramel? Yes. Pistachio? Yes. I apologize for not knowing the exact names, since I didn't choose them myself, but just get them all.  You won't be disappointed. 

I am strongly considering going with a selection of these for my wedding instead of cake.
author: Gloria A.

description: Haven't had to deal with unfriendly daughter, pastries very good but not five stars because of subtle changes to some of my favorites that seem geared toward profit over quality. Still, a very good pastry shop that's conveniently located.
author: M B.

description: just in case y'all are looking to get your own cronut... this place makes the cinnamon sugar cronut from wednesdays through sundays only between the hours of 9am to 11am. on saturdays, they make a "special flavor of the day" cronut. i hear that they usually post on their facebook page what flavor they're making on the morning of, but i didn't see one this morning. they had a custard filled one last week, a chocolate candy cane the week before, and a candied bacon and maple the week before that. i don't know why they call them "d's nutz" on their facebook page. makes it sound kinda gross. didn't know if i had to call them that when i was ordering, but then the people in front of me called it cronuts, so i went with that as well. (fyi: cronut is a trademark name used by a baker in ny - made famous by all the hype around the idea.) it's exactly what you would imagine a croissant mixed with a doughnut would be... soft, flaky, buttery... oh the butter... so good, you'll forget any diet you're currently on. damn it!
author: Charleston C.

description:
Cannot speak, "choking" on Doug (father) and Elana's (daughter) fantastic, artistic and  mouth watering dessert works of artistry.

Various fruit pies daily, an array of tasty Danish, and a buttery and moist lemon pound cake......AND bread pudding!!!  Every mouthful of the Boysenberry flavored, was consumed eagerly, in a matter of a few minutes.  

On Valentine's , Doug offered a sample of white chocolate hearts, which again did NOT disappoint.  Go....Go...GO there for a unforgettable  time in dessert heaven!!!   

Doug and Elana has definitely easily supplanted Patisserie Delanghe..
The former was nice, but Fillmore Bakeshop is a DESTINATION  spot, with immediate friendliness that will entice you to return...again and again..
..
author: Harold N.

description: Made three friends, drank coffee and had a focaccia at the same time. Signed a book, hugged a person, and called a cab. The ultimate SF experience. Not to mention the lipstick tip from the barista.
author: Mina J.

description: Fillmore Bakeshop and La Boulange (on Pine St) are STILL my favorite bakeries in SF (and I have not been to Tartine yet, and I am sure these all would be a comfortable threesome for me!!!)  I love the fresh and wholesome ingredients (real butter and ingredients...not like Costco or Safeway)...in moderation of course.  Fillmore Bakeshop has incredible foccacia on Saturdays (oops...I let out my secret).  One suggestion, however, is to have "bar" seating in the windows and on the side.  It's really frustrating to go there and want to relax, but the two tables are occupied...sometimes it's with a parent and child taking up one or two seats and throwing stuff on the floor.  Frustrating.  Do bar seating as it eliminates the strollers and toddlers from taking up all the table space.  Regardless I am still coming often but I would like to hang out and chat with fellow patrons and promote your GREAT goods!!!
author: L H.

description:
Truly a "mom and pop" shop... So rare now a days...  Upon stepping inside you will certainly catch a whiff  of something fresh from the oven and then you will see and  feel the passion Elena, her dad and her staff have for baking  and service... I especially love the  pies... loads of fruit filling  just sweet enough and a crunchy crust to go...  outstanding cookies as well...
Something for everyone...
author: William W.

description:
Elena made the most beautiful and delicious birthday cake for my daughter's 5th birthday!!

I was planning to buy a standard "Safeway cake" but there happened to be a parking space in front of the bakeshop, so I went in to check it out and I am so glad I did - admittedly a little more expensive than supermarket cake but TOTALLY worth it! Adults and kids both loved it. It actually tasted like real flavorful CAKE and ICING (not the usual sugary sweetness that passes for cake.) And working with Elena was delightful - she made exactly what I asked, even better than I imagined it. My daughter loved it : )

I know many people love the pastries here, but I wanted to let everyone know they make fabulous birthday cakes too - check it out!
author: Lisa K.

description: I went here a few weeks ago and was pleasantly surprised with the quality of pastries I bought.  I didn't quite know what to think when I went in, as the display was a little haphazard and the outside is very unassuming, but the food tasted great and I was happy to learn that the shop was family owned.  The woman at the register was nice and explained a recipe to my friend and I (who are both pastry chefs), but I was a little off-put when I heard her later turn to one of the bakers and  reprimand her for something small in front of a line of clients, which seemed unnecessary and unprofessional (hence the three - instead of four - star rating).
author: Jessica H.

description: Absolutely delicious:  the apple danishes, raspberry danishes, pies, cronuts - everything is absolutely great!  And the team is so pleasant and polite.  Love it.
author: Gabby M.

description:
before the ownership change, it used to great pastries and hit or miss service. 

today i walked in, and the atmosphere was friendly, joyous, and everyone seemed to be buzzing because of Xmas Eve. something tells me it's like that regardless of what day it is. 

got the plain croissant, coffee, and the almond and pistachio macaroons. everything was delicious (esp. the macaroons). cost: $7 i consider myself a coffee snob: love blue bottle, phillz, and ritual. the coffee they served was just as good, if not better than those places. i was shocked. 

of course i'll be back to try their other pastries, the cake, and bread pudding. i'm pretty sure i'll upgrade to 5 stars once i try more of their selections. my favs w/ the previous ownership used to be the mini eclairs and these mini minty yule logs. hopefully they're still making those, fingers crossed.
author: Maria A.

description: wow is all I can say! excellent coffee, amazing pastries and friendly staff. first time here, had a cronut and a blueberry lemon pastry. spouse had a ham cheese croissant that he devoured. will be back in am, sad I don't live closer! a great place near all the shops in Fillmore. highly recommend!
author: Susan M.

description: I was a huge fan of Patisserie Delanghe, and was really bummed when it closed.  The replacement, Fillmore Bakeshop, is all remodeled inside and very spiffy.  And they take credit cards, which is a huge plus.  But... on my first visit today I bought one of my Delanghe favorites, an eclair.  I was disappointed when I got home and took a look at it... the cream filling had a dark yellow crust!  A la cream filling that's been in a fridge overnight with no covering!  Sacre bleu!  And the bottom half of the pastry--the half that had been marinating in the cream overnight--was soggy!  This is not an improvement over Delanghe.  I'll give Fillmore Bakeshop another chance, because I really *want* it to be just as good.
author: Michael C.

description: So the Macaron hunt begins! and Fillmore does not disappoint! Love the crunchy texture of the macaron! Love the variety of flavours.. not to strong but enough to leave a lasting taste.
author: Amy C.

description: We have eaten at bakeries all over the city and throughout NYC and Paris. We have eaten at French Laundry, Cyrus, Daniel, Alain Ducasse.  We think we know good food that has been created with passion, and this place is a true find. Elena & Doug at the Fillmore Bakeshop are first-rate, utterly devoted pastry chefs. You can taste passion in the blueberry cream cheese danishes! The banana chocolate bread pudding will melt in your mouth. Try a few different things to really get a feel for how wonderful this new American pâtisserie truly is!
author: Erica J.

description: Had a wonderful croque en bouche cake from these folks the other night for a my husband's birthday party.  Cake tasted delicious! and looked wonderful, a tall pyramid of rum and plain custard puffs tied in a gold spun sugar ribbon!  Very showy and lovely.  And the father and daughter owners were helpful and nice to deal with.
author: Audrey F.

description: Some good baked goods here. Indifferent to rude counter staff, and floors  in need of  a major scrubbing keep me away at times.  In fact, the whole bakery is full of clutter not related to baking, which makes the whole place look messy.
author: Joe M.

description: Ooh and aahs all around please. French macaroons, muffins, cookies, cakes. Such a delight to be in here. Even better to buy. The people working here must get sick of customers asking..what's that? But you know what-it doesn't show on their face since they are always smiling!! You work at a bake shop, why wouldn't you smile?!  Anyways, best macaroons. Flakey outside yummy gooey inside
author: Madeline W.

description: Really wish Yelp would let me give zero stars. Tried this place 3-4 years ago not long after they took over the space from Patisserie Delanghe when its owners retired :(  . Went back today and it is still without a doubt THE MOST DISAPPOINTING CHOCOLATE CROISSANT IN SAN FRANCISCO. Let me paint you a picture: please imagine a cross-section of a typical chocolate croissant- only THERE"S ALMOST NO CHOCOLATE. Just a little dimple of chocolate on either side with 2.5 to 3 inches of dry plain croissant between running the entire length of the pastry. And calling this a pastry is generous. A croissant is something flaky and buttery that you can peel apart in golden layers (even a Pillsbury crescent roll baked by a grade school child can pull this off). But the so-called chocolate croissant from Fillmore Bakeshop is like a dry sponge. No flaky layers. No buttery flavor. Like a Safeway croissant- only much more of a disappointment because on Fillmore Street you/me/anyone expect and deserve something better.  If Fillmore Bakeshop would not bother attempting patisserie items like pain au chocolat, then they would not be insulting the 25 year legacy of the husband-and-wife team of Dominique and Marie-Jeanne Delanghe.  But for those of fortunate enough to have eaten the Delanghe pain au chocolat at the corner of Fillmore and Bush for years, you can't help but expect so much more.  Dear Fillmore (the neighborhood)- you all deserve better. I hope you will walk a bit further to somewhere better than Fillmore Bakeshop.  Even the name is totally unimaginative.  By the grace of heaven I live in the Mission 2 blocks from Cafe Tartine - but here's my suggestion that's not too far for my Fillmore friends to travel for a far superior pain au chocolat:  Le Marais Bakery in Cow Hollow:  http://www.lemaraisbakery.com/
author: Chris R.

description:
picked up some random items, 
2 x dark choc square = 4 stars
1 x eclair = 3.5 stars, good, but nothing special
1 x choc + pecan cookie = 3.5 stars, good, but nothing special

overall a good bakery, but I felt it was kinda pricey.
author: Vimal P.

description: I'm going to keep this review short. Their macarons are delicious (I recommend pistachio) and their bread pudding was divine. The macarons were light and chewy...just the way I like them. The owner (I think that was him) was very friendly and the person helping us with out order was also very nice. The other pastries (cookies, cakes, croissants, etc.) looked delicious and super fresh, but I do have to agree with others about the price. The macarons were almost $2 each and that's at least a good $.25-$.50 more than other bakeries. I love the area of the bakery. Only street parking. Just an overall cute and delicious neighborhood bakery!
author: Christiana R.

description: i don't even like french macaroons very much. they are usually too sweet and seem pointless because the second they touch your tongue they just melt away in your mouth. but someone brought some to work and i got my hands on a mint chocolate macaroon. i couldn't believe how good it was! maybe it was just because i'm obsessed with mint chocolate things, or maybe it's because it was actually that perfect. get your hands on some!
author: Regina C.

description: This review is for the macarons only. It's $2 and ENORMOUS. BUT it's the worst macarons I ever had. They have like 16 flavors some of which I feel should not have been invented. Macarons should be chewy and the filling should be thick and firm but Filmore's Bakeshop macarons is crispy and the fillings is soft and oozes out when bitten. The taste of the filling is too strong too, either too sweet or too sour or too much fragrance. Too many wild colors indicates too much artificial coloring.  They should discontinue selling these macarons.
author: Robert S.

description: First, I don't really like bananas. See, when I want to eat fruit to be healthy, a banana somehow seems too fatty.  And when I want dessert, a banana seems too healthy. What's the point of bananas? I don't know where they fit in, they suffer an identity crisis and I'll have no part of it.  That said, holy crap, this place's chocolate croissant banana bread pudding was effing awesome!  With all the rich gooey chocolatey goodness oozing in the bread pudding, i almost forgot there were bananas in this thing! Could it be...a newfound love of something with bananas in it?  Judging by how quickly I devoured the massive hunk o bread pudding, I'd say yes.  Try it. You'll be a convert too.  Ok, end of proselytizing. But in the words of Gwen Stefani, "This shit is bananas, B-A-N-A-N-A-S!"
author: Caroline I.

description: i love, love, love this bakeshop! their parisian macarons are so yummy and fluffy! the shell is pretty crumbly...very meringue like. i first started off by buying 5, and then once i took a bite of my green tea macaron i returned to buy more! i'm never in that area so i stocked up for my trip to the east bay. their macaron's here are tastier than bouchon's macaron! a must try!
author: Cherina A.

description: Best French macaroons and chocolates in town.   Try the Yuzu chocolates, strawberry and pistachio macaroon. All are superb.   Very affordable and fast-friendly service.
author: Josh G.

description: I came here with my best friend specially for their macaroons. It was a first for both of us so we were excited and had high expectations from all the hype. The staff were very friendly and didn't hurry us even though the shop was quite busy. A macaroon was about $2 each and there were a variety of flavors, such as lemon, mango, passion fruit, rose, green tea, etc. After carefully choosing which colorful macaroons to eat, we first tried the rose flavored macaroon. My Lithuanian friend described it as an orgasm in her mouth. I, myself, enjoyed the crunchy outside, chewy inside feel but the macaroon had a medicine-like aftertaste. Afterwards, I tried seven other flavors, but all had a hint of a bitter mediciney taste. I'm not sure if all macaroons are supposed to taste this way, but until I try some others, these are A-OK.
author: Julie K.

description: I just died and went to heaven. holy moly! the bread pudding with cherries was everything I dreamed of and more. So, I'll keep it short and sweet- AMAZING BAKE SHOP!!!!!
author: sarah s.

description: The French macarons were not satisfying. They were flaky, crumbly, and too sweet.  It lacked all the many wonderful different textures that a macaron is supposed to have. Plus, some (e.g, the green tea) didn't taste at all like it was supposed to, and many of them had no flavor and just tasted like sugar.  At $2 per macaron, you are better off getting your fix elsewhere.
author: Fah V.

description: One of the best damn bakeries.    I especially love their Napoleon, Apple Pie, and their Chocolate Banana Bread Pudding is heaven.  The owners are a delight.  Lovely place.
author: Arman A.

description: We were in SF on vacation, staying in Japantown and wandering the neighborhood looking for a bit of breakfast when we passed the bakeshop. We went back every morning we were there for another baked treat and a delicious latte. We had chocolate croissant, cherry danish, blueberry danish, breakfast bun, bearclaw. All light, flaky, tasty. We also had wonderful chats with the folks behind the counter. The more elaborate desserts like cakes looked artistically amazing. On Saturday, they do a "raspberry hamburger" -- whole berries surrounding a cream center, sandwiched by two pink macarons. I didn't dare, but you should.
author: David G.

description: Great baked goods and great service! My favorite so far has been the mini-eclairs. There is so much to choose from. I think I'll have to go there 20 times just to try everything they have to offer!
author: Jessica S.

description: This place is amazing!  I have had pastries from other spots in SF, but the Filmore Bakeshop blows me away.  I had a croissant with chocolate chip filling and it was to die for.  The croissant tasted so fresh and didn't leave me feeling gross after like many pastries from other bakeries have in the past.  This pastry definitely made my morning!  If you haven't been here yet, do it!
author: Jessica A.

description:
This place is wonderful. I never tried the bakery it replaced, but happened to make it in here on opening day-- and half a dozen times since then.

The pastries are consistently delicious, they serve amazing la colombe coffee (a little taste of philadelphia-- in a good way!) and the atmosphere is fabulous. Every person I've spoken to inside made my day just a little bit brighter. 

Not much in the way of seating-- there are a few tiny tables-- but it would be a good spot for people watching if one happened to be vacant.
author: Rachel F.

description: Ginger chocolate macaroons are amazing!  Also tried the chocolate banana bread pudding and it was yummy!
author: Lisa S.

description: My favorite from Fillmore Bakeshop is cherry pie and I always pre-order a whole pie. It always tastes as though they've put thought and care in making them. I often bring out-of-town guests here to grab some pastries for a quick breakfast. I'm not really a fan of their macarons, but that's ok because they have other great items like a special shortbread-like cookie covered in chocolate. Friendly customer service!
author: Elizabeth D.

description: The macarons were just mediocre and did not wow me at all. I tried the raspberry, rose, and salted caramel. The salted caramel tasted more like chocolate than caramel, and the raspberry needed more intense raspberry tartness. Their macarons are pretty hard, and I didn't like that much. I've had excellent macarons where the interior is chewy, but not hard. The only hard (crunchy) part should be the thin skin on the outside. That is the perfect macaron.
author: Michael F.

description: the princess cake is unreal... spent the better part of a half hour moaning with pleasure at each nibble whilst swimming in princess blankets of suppleness... that probably makes no sense at all but neither does how  f***ing good this cake is
author: Pax, Formerly Known As Rufus D.

description: We found this bakeshop on yelp. When we went there, I ordered hot chocolate, and it came with latte. The clerk guy was really nice. We went there again for breakfast on our last day in SF because the food and service is really amazing! We went there right before we left and they remembered everything we ordered the last time. All the Danishes were really delicious and there were all kinds of croissants which were all crispy and SUPER delicious. Also, my brother ordered the homemade bun (or something). It was very fresh and soft and delicious. Everything in there tastes like heaven.
author: Janet L.

description: Elena worked with me to select an assortment of petit fours, mini eclairs,  cream puffs and cookies for a birthday tea.  The guests at the event RAVED about the desserts we served--especially the mini eclairs!  Elena's suggestions were very helpful; we had a lovely assortment and the prices were less than at other upscale bakeries in San Francisco.  I'll definitely return to this bakery again, and highly recommend the owners and staff.
author: Maureen F.

description: The Fillmore Bakeshop is one block from my work, and I am thankful everyday for this place of yumminess. I am obsessed with the Apple danishes, but what really gets me drooling is the chocolate salted caramel cake. It is beyond words, it is just that good. Second on my favorites list is the mango/passion fruit chiffon cake. If I could live there, I would.
author: Shirley L.

description: i rode my bike here from the panhandle to get last minute macarons for my sister's birthday. they have like 15 flavors, all huge and delicious. a small shop but all smiles and sweetness. these are good people hard at work, you can just see it. will definitely go back :)
author: Mitch N.

description: Pecan Sandies. These cookies melt in your mouth and have a great crunch at the same time. Perfection. German chocolate cupcakes - when these are the cupcake of the day jump on that. Lemon pound cake? Holy Cow is that tasty. Savory? Try the ham and cheese croissant or a slice of quiche. Something for everyone here at this wonderful bake shop. Warm, funny and friendly owners. Yes, they took over a beloved institution, and raised the bar. You've been good -  treat yourself to a visit. The bread pudding? Heaven. The pies? Better. The cakes a feast for the eyes.
author: Nanette B.

description: Best ______ ever!  (fill in the blank with anything they make).  I've never had morning buns, and after trying one at Fillmore Bakeshop, I tried several more at other bakeries and none of them stand up to the one at Fillmore Bakeshop. The banana chocolate bread pudding is delicious, moist all the way through sweet and rich, but surprisingly not too heavy. I'm never disappointed, (except when I tried hot cross buns...I'm just personally not a fan, but I know for those who do like them REALLY like them at the Fillmore Bakeshop)
author: L C.

description: I will always have fond memories of De Langhe Patisserie for their delicious goodies as well as their friendship.  I will also say that the Fillmore Bakeshop is a wonderful experience and I wish them well as the treats are fabulous and offer some of the old delights while offering many new goodies with their own twist!!!  I love the cookies, pies and chocolates.. Doug was nice enough to make a birthday cake with a 6 hours notice and what a beautiful delight it was!  I wish this father- daughter team "Doug and Elena" the best as they are a sweet addition to the neighborhood!!
author: SUSAN S.

description: First off, the people there are so nice. Service top notch. Both the owners were extremely attentive asked me if I needed help. Everyone working there seemed very happy and updeat. Everything I ordered was top-notch. Good to see a small business get both parts right...the service and the food.
author: Lionel C.

description: The Salted Caramel Chocolate Mousse Cake is one of the  top 5 desserts in San Francisco.  Everything else is very good as well.  Also a big fan of their Princess Cake.
author: L E.

description: my kids love the cookies, my husband loved the fruit tart and I thought the coffee was surprisingly good.  Great experience we will definitely be going back.
author: mama s.

description: The bakery has the most amazing pastries. I got the almond croissant and the cinnamon roll. They were delicious. The workers are very friendly and the atmosphere is welcoming and happy. I love the macaroons!!
author: I believe I.
